questions.text: The flexion point in a ventouse delivery is located at which of the following positions on the fetal head?

choices.text: 3 cm posterior to the anterior fontanelle
3 cm anterior to the posterior fontanelle
6 cm anterior to the posterior fontanelle
Midway between the anterior and posterior fontanelle

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - 3 cm anterior to the posterior fontanelle:

  • The flexion point, crucial for ventouse delivery, is located 3 cm anterior to the posterior fontanelle. Placing the ventouse cup here helps achieve proper flexion of the fetal head, leading to the smallest diameter (suboccipitobregmatic) of the head passing through the birth canal.

Incorrect Option:

Option A - 3 cm posterior to the anterior fontanelle:

  • This option refers to a point on the fetal head closer to the posterior fontanelle but is not accurate for the flexion point used in ventouse delivery.

Option C - 6 cm anterior to the posterior fontanelle:

  • This would place the point closer to the anterior fontanelle, which is not the correct position for the flexion point in ventouse delivery.

Option D - Midway between the anterior and posterior fontanelle:

This is a central point on the fetal head, but it is not the specific flexion point used for ventouse delivery, which is 3 cm anterior to the posterior fontanelle.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding Samter's triad?

choices.text: It is only triggered by aspirin.
Other NSAIDs with COX-1 blocking ability can also trigger symptoms.
It is characterized by asthma, nasal polyps, and aspirin sensitivity.

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - It is only triggered by aspirin (Incorrect Statement):

  • This statement is incorrect because Samter's triad, also known as aspirin-exacerbated respiratory disease (AERD), can be triggered not only by aspirin but also by other nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) that inhibit cyclooxygenase-1 (COX-1). These include ibuprofen, naproxen, and others that block COX-1. Therefore, patients with Samter's triad must avoid all COX-1 inhibiting NSAIDs, not just aspirin.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Other NSAIDs with COX-1 blocking ability can also trigger symptoms (Correct Statement):

  • This is a correct statement. In Samter's triad, the use of NSAIDs that inhibit COX-1 can trigger symptoms like asthma exacerbation, nasal congestion, and other respiratory issues due to their impact on the arachidonic acid pathway, leading to increased production of leukotrienes.

Option C - It is characterized by asthma, nasal polyps, and aspirin sensitivity (Correct Statement):

  • This is a correct statement. Samter's triad is defined by the presence of three key features: asthma, chronic rhinosinusitis with nasal polyps, and sensitivity to aspirin or other COX-1 inhibiting NSAIDs.

Option D - It involves overproduction of leukotrienes (Correct Statement):

  • Explanation: This is a correct statement. In Samter's triad, the inhibition of COX-1 by aspirin or NSAIDs leads to the overproduction of leukotrienes, which are inflammatory mediators that contribute to the symptoms of asthma, nasal polyps, and other respiratory issues.

questions.text: Sour taste is perceived by which receptors?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - TRPP3:

  • TRPP3 (also known as PKD2L1) is a receptor involved in the perception of sour taste. It detects acidic (sour) stimuli by responding to the presence of protons (H+ ions) in the food.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - T1R1: This receptor is primarily associated with detecting umami taste, often in combination with T1R3. It does not play a role in sour taste perception.

Option B - T1R2: T1R2, along with T1R3, is involved in the perception of sweet taste. It is not responsible for detecting sour taste.

Option C - T1R3: T1R3 pairs with T1R1 for umami taste and with T1R2 for sweet taste. It is not involved in the perception of sour taste.

questions.text: What instrument is used to insert this tube?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Cysto-urethroscope:

  • This is the correct instrument for inserting a tube to access the urinary tract. It is used to visualize the bladder and urethra through the urethra, allowing for the insertion of various tubes or instruments for diagnostic or therapeutic purposes.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Nephroscope: This instrument is specifically used to visualize and treat conditions within the kidney. It is typically employed for procedures such as percutaneous nephrolithotomy (PCNL) to remove kidney stones. It is not used for inserting tubes into the urinary tract.

Option C - Ureteroscope: This instrument is used to visualize and treat conditions within the ureters (the tubes connecting the kidneys to the bladder). It is used for procedures such as ureteroscopy to remove stones or diagnose issues in the ureters, but not typically for inserting a tube into the urinary tract.

Option D - Endoscope: While endoscopes are used for visualizing internal body structures, they are not specific to the urinary tract. The term "endoscope" encompasses a wide range of instruments used for various types of internal examination, including but not limited to cystoscopes, colonoscopes, and bronchoscopes.

questions.text: A 13-year-old boy presents with jaundice, fatigue, muscle stiffness, tremors, behavioral changes, hepatosplenomegaly, and Kayser-Fleischer rings. Which test is definitive for the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Hepatic parenchymal copper concentration

Explanation:

  • The clinical presentation of jaundice, fatigue, muscle stiffness, tremors, behavioral changes, hepatosplenomegaly, and Kayser-Fleischer rings(most specific) suggests Wilson's disease and measuring the Hepatic parenchymal copper concentration is the most definitive test for diagnosis of Wilson's disease.

Wilson Disease:

Aspect

Details

Definition

Autosomal recessive disorder of copper metabolism leading to copper accumulation in tissues.

Gene Affected

ATP7B gene mutation on chromosome 13.(Option D) -Helpful, but ATP7B has many mutations; testing can miss variants, and results take time.

Pathophysiology
  • Defective copper transport leads to:
  • Decreased copper incorporation into ceruloplasmin.
  • Impaired biliary excretion of copper.
  • Copper accumulates in the liver, spills into the bloodstream, and deposits in various tissues.

Clinical Features

Hepatic
  • Acute hepatitis
  • Chronic liver disease (cirrhosis)
  • Fulminant hepatic failure

Neurological
  • Dysarthria
  • Movement disorders (tremors, dystonia, chorea)
  • Rigidity, bradykinesia

Psychiatric
  • Depression, irritability, or psychosis
  • Cognitive decline

Ophthalmological
  • Kayser-Fleischer rings (golden-brown ring at the corneal margin due to copper deposition) in slit lamp examination.
  • Sunflower cataracts (less common)

Diagnosis

Biochemical
  • Gold standard: Elevated hepatic copper content on liver biopsy (>250 µg/g dry weight) (Option C)
  • Low serum ceruloplasmin (<20 mg/dL) (Option B)
  • Elevated 24-hour urinary copper excretion (>100 µg/day) (Option A)

Imaging

Brain MRI: Hyperintensities in basal ganglia (e.g., "face of the giant panda" sign in the midbrain)

Treatment

Copper Chelation

D-Penicillamine (binds and increases urinary copper excretion)

Copper Absorption Blockers

Zinc salts: Compete with copper absorption in the gut

Dietary

Low-copper diet (avoid shellfish, nuts, chocolate, liver)

Liver Transplant

For severe liver failure or unresponsive cases

questions.text: A singer is finding difficulty in raising the pitch of her voice. On examination, her vocal cords were depressed and bowing. Which of the following muscles is involved?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Cricothyroid:

  • The cricothyroid muscle is crucial for raising the pitch of the voice. It is a tensor muscle of the vocal cords. When there is dysfunction or paralysis of the cricothyroid muscle, the vocal cords are not properly tensed, leading to difficulty in raising the pitch.

Incorrect Options:

Option B and D - Interarytenoid and Lateral arytenoid are adductors of the vocal cord.

Option C - The posterior cricoarytenoid is an abductor of the vocal cords.

questions.text: A patient presents with fever, hepatosplenomegaly, abdominal pain, and WBC count > 50,000/mm3. Which of the following genetic abnormalities is involved?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - t(9;22):

  • The given clinical features are suggestive of chronic myeloid leukemia, and the genetic abnormality associated with it is translocation of t(9;22).

 

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C, and D are not associated with CML.

questions.text: A fruit farmer presents with fever, respiratory difficulties, and neurological complications. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Nipah:

  • Nipah virus is a zoonotic virus that fruit farmers are particularly at risk of contracting due to its association with fruit bats. It presents with fever, respiratory difficulties, and severe neurological complications, including encephalitis, making it the most likely diagnosis in this case.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Ebola: Ebola virus primarily causes hemorrhagic fever with symptoms like severe bleeding, multi-organ failure, and shock. While it can present with fever and some neurological complications, respiratory symptoms are not typical, and there is no specific association with fruit farming.

Option B - Meningitis: Meningitis causes inflammation of the meninges surrounding the brain and spinal cord, leading to fever, headache, neck stiffness, and neurological complications. However, respiratory symptoms are uncommon, and the condition is not linked to fruit farming.

Option D - Zika: Zika virus primarily causes mild symptoms like fever, rash, and joint pain, and is more famous for its complications during pregnancy, such as microcephaly in newborns. It does not commonly cause severe respiratory or neurological issues, nor is it specifically associated with fruit farming.

questions.text: Which of the following vaccine is kept at lowest level?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - OPV:

  • The OPV (Oral Polio Vaccine) is kept at the lowest level in Intermediate-Level Refrigerators (ILRs) compared to the other vaccines listed.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - DPT (Diphtheria, Pertussis, Tetanus): DPT is a combination vaccine and is sensitive to temperature changes. It needs to be stored in a controlled environment to maintain its efficacy, typically at a temperature range of 2°C to 8°C in ILRs.

Option C - Hep B (Hepatitis B Vaccine): Hepatitis B vaccine is sensitive to temperature and must be kept at a stable temperature of 2°C to 8°C, similar to DPT, but it is more sensitive to freezing. Thus, it requires careful monitoring to avoid freezing.

Option D - Rota (Rotavirus Vaccine): The Rotavirus vaccine is sensitive to temperature fluctuations and is generally stored in ILRs at 2°C to 8°C. However, it is often kept at a higher level in the cold chain to ensure stability.

questions.text: A mother delivers in a rural area under the guidance of a skilled care attendant. Which of the following is incorrect regarding the care provided by the skilled care attendant at birth?

choices.text: Start breastfeeding as early as possible
Cover the baby's head and body
Bathe the baby with warm water
Clear eyes with a sterile swab

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Bathe the baby with warm water:

  • This option is incorrect because immediate bathing can lead to hypothermia and is discouraged right after birth. Instead, the focus should be on keeping the baby warm and starting breastfeeding.


Incorrect Options:

Option A - Start breastfeeding as early as possible: Early initiation of breastfeeding, ideally within the first hour of birth, is crucial for the baby’s health. It helps with bonding, provides essential nutrients, and supports the infant's immune system.

Option B - Cover the baby's head and body: Covering the baby’s head and body immediately after birth is important to prevent heat loss and maintain the baby’s body temperature, especially in rural or resource-limited settings.

Option D - Clear eyes with a sterile swab: Clearing the baby’s eyes with a sterile swab helps prevent eye infections, which is part of routine newborn care.

questions.text: What is the ideal pressure setting for vacuum-assisted closure (VAC) therapy?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - 125 mm Hg:

  • This is the most commonly recommended and studied pressure setting for VAC therapy. It is considered ideal for promoting wound healing, reducing edema, and enhancing blood flow while minimizing tissue damage. Most clinical guidelines and studies support this pressure as the optimal setting for standard VAC therapy.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - 60 to 80 mm Hg: This lower pressure range may be used in specific situations, such as when treating wounds over sensitive or delicate areas where higher pressures might cause discomfort or tissue damage. However, it is generally not considered the ideal setting for most VAC applications.

Option C - 130 mm Hg: Although close to the recommended pressure, this slightly higher setting may increase the risk of tissue damage and discomfort, making it less ideal compared to the 125 mm Hg setting.

Option D - 80 to 100 mm Hg: This range may be used for certain wounds where a lower pressure is needed, such as in patients with compromised circulation or delicate tissues. However, it is not the standard pressure setting for VAC therapy in most cases.

questions.text: An infant presents with vomiting after feeding. A Benedict’s test was performed and returned positive for a non-glucose substance. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Galactosemia due to GAL-1-P uridyl transferase enzyme deficiency
Hereditary fructose intolerance due to aldolase B deficiency
Galactosemia due to galactokinase enzyme deficiency

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Galactosemia due to GAL-1-P uridyl transferase enzyme deficiency:

  • This is the most likely diagnosis, given the presentation of vomiting after feeding and a positive Benedict’s test for a non-glucose substance, consistent with the presence of galactose in the urine.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Hereditary fructose intolerance due to aldolase B deficiency:

  • Hereditary fructose intolerance results from a deficiency in aldolase B, leading to the accumulation of fructose-1-phosphate after ingestion of fructose, sucrose, or sorbitol. Symptoms include vomiting, hypoglycemia, and liver damage. The Benedict’s test would show a positive result for fructose, but this condition typically presents after the introduction of fructose-containing foods, not in the newborn period.

Option C - Glucose-6-Phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency:

  • G6PD deficiency leads to hemolytic anemia, particularly after exposure to certain triggers like infections or certain foods/drugs. This condition does not typically cause a positive Benedict’s test for a non-glucose substance, nor does it present with vomiting after feeding.

Option D - Galactosemia due to galactokinase enzyme deficiency:

  • This milder form of galactosemia results from a deficiency in galactokinase, leading to the accumulation of galactose, which can cause cataracts. However, it usually does not cause severe systemic symptoms like those seen in GAL-1-P uridyl transferase deficiency, and the Benedict’s test would still be positive for galactose.

questions.text: Identify the instrument shown below:
questions.solution:
Correct Option C – Pipers:

  • Pipers forceps are specifically designed for the delivery of the after-coming head in breech presentations. They are characterized by a reverse pelvic curve, allowing safe application to the head during breech delivery, which is crucial for avoiding injury to the baby’s head and neck.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Kielland:

  • Kielland forceps are designed with a sliding lock and minimal pelvic curve, often used for rotational deliveries in cases of fetal malposition. They are known for their distinct ability to rotate the fetal head.

Option B - Wrigley:

  • Wrigley forceps are smaller, lighter forceps primarily used for low-forceps deliveries or during cesarean sections to assist in delivering the baby’s head. They have a short length, making them ideal for low pelvic use.

questions.text: What does JSSK stand for?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Janani Shishu Suraksha Karyakram:

  • The Janani Shishu Suraksha Karyakram (JSSK) is a scheme launched by the Government of India to provide free and cashless healthcare services to pregnant women, mothers, and newborns. The program aims to reduce maternal and infant mortality rates by ensuring that all pregnant women and newborns have access to essential healthcare services without financial constraints.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options B, C, and D are incorrect as given above.

questions.text: A 12-year-old child presents to the outpatient department (OPD) with a complaint of scrotal pain, with a history of trauma 6 hours prior. Upon surgical exploration, the findings suggest significant damage. What is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Torsion of testicular appendages with gangrene

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Testicular torsion with gangrene:

  • Testicular torsion occurs when the spermatic cord twists, cutting off the blood supply to the testicle. If untreated for several hours, this can lead to gangrene due to ischemia. The history of trauma and rapid onset of pain, along with surgical findings, strongly suggest testicular torsion with gangrene.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Torsion of testicular appendages with gangrene:

  • Torsion of testicular appendages, such as the appendix testis, is less common and usually presents with localized pain. While it can cause significant discomfort, it typically does not lead to the severe ischemia and gangrene seen in testicular torsion.
  • Blue dot sign: torsion of appendage of testis

Option C - Gangrene:

  • Gangrene refers to tissue death due to loss of blood supply. In this context, the term alone is nonspecific, and without the identification of an underlying cause, such as testicular torsion, it does not fully describe the condition.

Option D - Hematoma:

  • A hematoma can occur due to trauma, leading to localized swelling and pain. However, it would not typically present with the severe ischemic changes seen in testicular torsion unless associated with vascular injury.

questions.text: A patient presents with painful vesicles in the genital region. Identify the lesion shown in the image and choose the correct diagnosis:
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Herpes:

  • Bilateral painful vesicles, along with painful inguinal lymphadenopathy, are seen in HSV-2 infection.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Chancroid: Chancroid causes painful ulcers but typically presents as a single, larger ulcer with ragged edges, not multiple vesicles.

Option C - Syphilis: Syphilis causes painless genital ulcers.

Option D - Candidiasis: Candidiasis does not cause painful vesicular lesions.

questions.text: Which neonatal anomaly is depicted in the image?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Exstrophy bladder:

  • Exstrophy bladder is characterized by the exposure of the bladder outside the body due to a defect in the lower abdominal wall. This anomaly results in a visible protrusion of the bladder, which is a key feature differentiating it from other conditions such as omphalocele, gastroschisis, and patent vitello intestinal duct.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Omphalocele:

  • This is a congenital defect where the abdominal organs herniate into the base of the umbilical cord due to a defect in the abdominal wall. It is covered by a translucent sac, which is a distinguishing feature.

Option B - Gastroschisis:

  • This is a defect in the abdominal wall where the intestines protrude outside the body through a hole next to the umbilicus. Unlike omphalocele, gastroschisis does not have a protective sac covering the exposed organs.

Option C - Patent vitello intestinal duct:

  • This anomaly occurs when the duct that connects the fetal intestine to the yolk sac fails to close properly, leading to the formation of a persistent connection between the umbilicus and the intestine, which may result in a small cyst or opening near the umbilicus.

questions.text: A patient presents with xanthomas on the Achilles tendon. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Familial hypercholesterolemia:

  • Familial hypercholesterolemia (FH) is an inherited disorder characterized by high levels of low-density lipoprotein (LDL) cholesterol in the blood. Xanthomas, which are deposits of cholesterol in the skin or tendons, are a hallmark of this condition

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options B, C, and D do not present with tendon xanthomas.

questions.text: Patient is having a headache and confusion. A brain tumor diagnosis is made. Family history reveals brain and kidney tumors. Choose the correct option:
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - VHL syndrome:

  • Von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) syndrome is a genetic condition characterized by the development of various tumors, including brain tumors (often hemangioblastomas), kidney tumors (renal cell carcinoma), and other tumors like pheochromocytomas. The family history of both brain and kidney tumors aligns with VHL syndrome. This condition is due to mutations in the VHL gene.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Neurofibromatosis: Neurofibromatosis (NF) has two main types: NF1 and NF2. NF1 is associated with cutaneous neurofibromas, café-au-lait spots, and optic nerve tumors, while NF2 is associated with bilateral vestibular schwannomas (acoustic neuromas) and other central nervous system tumors. Although brain tumors are present, NF does not typically present with kidney tumors.

Option B - Li-Fraumeni syndrome: Li-Fraumeni syndrome is a hereditary condition associated with a higher risk of several cancers, including breast cancer, sarcomas, brain tumors, and adrenal cortex tumors. While it is associated with brain tumors, it is not typically associated with kidney tumors. The syndrome is caused by mutations in the TP53 gene.

Option D - Churg-Strauss syndrome: Churg-Strauss syndrome, now known as eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis (EGPA), is an autoimmune condition that affects small and medium-sized blood vessels. It primarily involves respiratory symptoms, asthma, and vasculitis, but it is not associated with brain and kidney tumors.

questions.text: A man presents with back pain following road traffic accident. There was no history of neurological deficit. X ray spine is done. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Spinous Process Fracture:

  • A spinous process fracture occurs when the bony projection off the back of a vertebra is broken. Hyperextension injuries typically cause this type of fracture and often presents with localized back pain without neurological deficits. X-rays show a fracture of the spinous process, but the vertebral body remains intact as given in the image.

Incorrect options:

Option B - Chance Fracture:

  • A Chance fracture, also known as a seatbelt fracture, is a type of spinal injury caused by hyperflexion of the spine, often associated with a lap belt during a car accident. It is characterized by a fracture through the vertebral body and posterior elements. On X-ray, it shows a horizontal fracture line through the vertebral body, which might be difficult to identify if only the spinous process is imaged.

 

Option C - Fracture of the Base of Vertebrae:

  • This type of fracture involves a break at the base of the vertebra, which could affect the anterior or posterior aspects of the vertebra. It may not always present with neurological symptoms immediately but could lead to instability. It might not always be obvious on X-rays unless specific views are used.

Option D - Compressed Fracture:

  • A compression fracture involves the collapse of the vertebral body, often due to axial load or trauma. It presents with back pain and is typically visible on X-rays as a decrease in vertebral body height. In the absence of neurological deficits, this is a common type of fracture resulting from trauma.

questions.text: A child presents with growth failure. Biochemical analysis shows normal ca2+, normal PTH, reduced phosphate, and increased ALP. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Hypophosphatemic Rickets:

  • The biochemical findings of reduced phosphate and increased ALP with normal calcium and normal PTH are characteristic of hypophosphatemic rickets. This condition results from a defect in renal phosphate reabsorption, leading to low phosphate levels despite normal calcium and parathyroid hormone levels

Incorrect Options

Option A - Nutritional Rickets:

  • Cause: Typically due to a deficiency in vitamin D, calcium, or phosphate.
  • Biochemical Profile: Often presents with low calcium, high phosphate, and elevated ALP.

Option C - Type 1 Vitamin D Dependent Rickets (VDDR Type 1):

  • Cause: Due to a deficiency in 1-alpha-hydroxylase enzyme, which converts vitamin D to its active form.
  • Biochemical Profile: Typically presents with low calcium, low phosphate, and elevated PTH, along with increased ALP.

Option D -Type 2 Vitamin D Dependent Rickets (VDDR Type 2):

  • Cause: Due to a receptor defect that impairs the action of active vitamin D on bone.
  • Biochemical Profile: May show normal or high calcium, low phosphate, elevated PTH, and high ALP.

questions.text: A patient presents to the outpatient department with an ulcerated breast tumor and liver metastasis. What is the appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Neoadjuvant chemotherapy followed by surgery:

  • For stage 4 breast cancer with distant metastases (such as liver metastasis), the primary goal is to downstage the disease and reduce the tumor burden before considering surgical intervention. Neoadjuvant chemotherapy (chemotherapy given before surgery) helps shrink the tumor and potentially the metastatic sites, making subsequent surgery more feasible. In some cases, surgery may be considered after effective systemic treatment has been achieved, depending on the response to chemotherapy and the overall treatment plan.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Simple mastectomy: This procedure involves the removal of the entire breast but does not address regional lymph nodes or distant metastases. It is not appropriate for stage 4 breast cancer with liver metastasis, as the disease has spread beyond the breast and regional nodes.

Option B - Modified Radical Mastectomy (MRM): This involves the removal of the breast along with the axillary lymph nodes. While it is a more extensive surgery compared to a simple mastectomy, it is still not sufficient for stage 4 breast cancer with distant metastasis. This approach does not address the metastatic disease in the liver.

Option C - Radical mastectomy: This is an extensive surgical procedure that involves removal of the breast, axillary lymph nodes, and underlying chest muscles. Like the previous options, it is not appropriate for stage 4 breast cancer with liver metastasis, as the cancer has already spread beyond the breast and regional lymph nodes.

questions.text: Identify the disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Renal cyst:

  • Renal cyst will show a unilocular cystic lesion as given in the image

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Renal tumor: Renal tumors, such as renal cell carcinoma, are solid masses in the kidneys that are malignant or benign. They are characterized by abnormal growth of cells rather than fluid-filled sacs.

Option C - Autosomal Dominant Polycystic Kidney Disease (ADPKD): ADPKD is a genetic disorder characterized by the formation of multiple fluid-filled cysts in both kidneys. This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern and can lead to kidney failure over time.

Option D - Hydatid cyst: Hydatid cysts are caused by a parasitic infection (Echinococcus) and are typically found in the liver or lungs rather than the kidneys. They are not associated with genetic predisposition.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman is diagnosed with right vestibular neuronitis. What findings are expected during the head impulse test in this patient?

choices.text: When the head is turned to the left, the eyeballs move to the left with nystagmus.
When the head is turned to the left, the eyeballs move to the right with nystagmus.
When the head is turned to the right, the eyeballs move to the left with nystagmus.
When the head is turned to the right, the eyeballs move to the right with nystagmus.

questions.solution:
Correct Option: C) When the head is turned to the right, the eyeballs move to the left with nystagmus

Explanation:

  • The head impulse test is a clinical maneuver used to assess the function of the vestibulo-ocular reflex (VOR), which stabilizes gaze during head movement.
  • In a patient with right vestibular neuronitis, the right vestibular nerve is impaired. When the head is turned to the right:
    • The right vestibular system fails to generate the appropriate signal to maintain gaze.
    • The eyes initially move with the head to the right (which is abnormal) and then perform a quick corrective movement (catch-up saccade) to the left to refocus on the target.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, B and D are incorrect, as explained above.

questions.text: Which of the following is the anticoagulation of choice for a pregnant female at 36 weeks of gestation?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Heparin:

  • Heparin, specifically unfractionated heparin (UFH), is the anticoagulant of choice in late pregnancy ( At/more than 36 weeks). Heparin does not cross the placenta, making it safe for the fetus.
  • In the final weeks of pregnancy, UFH is preferred over low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) like enoxaparin because it has a shorter half-life and can be quickly reversed if needed during labor or in case of delivery.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Warfarin:

  • Warfarin is a vitamin K antagonist and is contraindicated during pregnancy, especially in the third trimester, due to its teratogenic effects and risk of fetal bleeding. Warfarin can cross the placenta and may cause fetal complications such as fetal warfarin syndrome and intracranial hemorrhage.

Option C - Apixaban:

  • Apixaban is a direct oral anticoagulant (DOAC) that is not recommended during pregnancy due to limited data on its safety and the risk of placental transfer. It is not typically used in pregnant women.

Option D - Enoxaparin:

Enoxaparin is a low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) and is safe during most of the pregnancy. However, as the patient approaches delivery (around 36 weeks), treatment is often switched to unfractionated heparin due to the need for rapid reversal at the time of labor or delivery.

questions.text: A patient does not understand the meaning of the doctor's words. Which type of barrier is this?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Linguistic 

When a patient does not understand the meaning of the doctor’s words, the barrier is due to language or communication issues, which is classified as a linguistic barrier.

  • This may be due to use of complex medical terms, different languages, accents, or poor language comprehension.

  • It impairs effective doctor–patient communication.

Classification of Communication Barriers:

Type Description Example
Cultural Differences in beliefs, values, or customs A patient rejecting treatment due to cultural beliefs
Linguistic Barriers related to language or word usage A patient not understanding medical terminology
Psychological Related to emotions, stress, anxiety, or mental health A patient too anxious to listen or comprehend
Environmental Due to external distractions like noise, poor lighting, or space A consultation held in a noisy hospital corridor

 

Cultural (Option A):
Incorrect – This would involve a conflict in beliefs or practices, not merely misunderstanding words.

Psychological (Option C):
Incorrect – This applies when emotional or mental states interfere with understanding, not language itself.

Environmental (Option D):
Incorrect – Environmental barriers refer to physical surroundings, not comprehension of spoken words.

questions.text: A football player had a twist in the ankle and knee. Clinically, no bony injury was appreciated. The examiner is performing a test to assess the knee joint. Which test is this?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Lachman Test:

  • This test evaluates the anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) by assessing the stability of the knee. With the knee flexed at approximately 20-30 degrees, the examiner stabilizes the femur with one hand and pulls the tibia forward with the other. Increased forward movement of the tibia relative to the femur indicates ACL injury.

 

Incorrect OptionS:

Option A - Posterior Drawer for PCL:

  • This test assesses the integrity of the posterior cruciate ligament (PCL). The examiner applies a posterior force to the tibia while the patient is in a supine position with the knee flexed. A positive test shows excessive posterior movement of the tibia relative to the femur, indicating PCL injury.

Option B - McMurray Test:

  • This test is used to assess meniscal tears. The examiner rotates the tibia while the knee is flexed and extended. Pain or a "click" during this maneuver suggests a meniscal tear, but it is not specific for ligament injuries.

Option D - Anterior Drawer for ACL:

  • This test is also used to assess the ACL. The patient lies supine with the knee flexed at 90 degrees. The examiner pulls the tibia forward while stabilizing the femur. Increased anterior movement of the tibia relative to the femur indicates ACL injury.

questions.text: Which drug is used in the maintenance phase of opioid withdrawal?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A – Buprenorphine:

  • Buprenorphine is used in the maintenance phase of opioid withdrawal.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Disulfiram:

  • It is not used in opioid withdrawal. It is primarily used in the treatment of alcohol dependence.

Option C – Butorphanol:

  • It is not used during the maintenance phase of opioid withdrawal.

Option D - Clonidine:

  • It is used in the detoxification phase in an opioid-addicted patient who is unwilling to be treated with opioids

questions.text: Aprepitant, a drug used to prevent late-onset chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting, acts through which of the following mechanisms?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - NK-1 Antagonist:

  • Mechanism of Action: Aprepitant is a selective antagonist of the neurokinin-1 (NK-1) receptor. By blocking the NK-1 receptors, aprepitant inhibits the action of substance P, a neuropeptide involved in the emetic pathway. This helps to prevent nausea and vomiting, particularly the late-onset type associated with chemotherapy.
  • Use: It is effective in managing delayed chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting (CINV) when used in combination with other antiemetic agents.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - NK-1 Agonist:

  • This is incorrect because aprepitant is not an agonist but an antagonist of the NK-1 receptor. An NK-1 agonist would stimulate the receptor, potentially increasing the risk of nausea and vomiting rather than preventing it.

Option C - NK-3 Antagonist:

  • Aprepitant does not act on the NK-3 receptors. NK-3 receptors are another subtype of neurokinin receptors, and antagonists targeting these receptors are not used in the treatment of chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting.

Option D - NK-2 Antagonist:

  • Aprepitant is not an NK-2 antagonist. NK-2 receptors are another subtype involved in the emetic response, but aprepitant specifically targets the NK-1 receptors. NK-2 antagonists are not the primary agents used for preventing chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting.

questions.text: Identify the logo?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Leprosy:

  • The above given logo refers to Leprosy/Hansen's Disease.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options B, C and D are incorrect as given above.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with a long-standing history of “feeling tensed” along with an upset stomach, diarrhea, and heartburn. She mentions that her family members also experience similar symptoms. Which of the following symptoms is most likely to be observed in this patient?
questions.solution:
Answer: B) Tingling at extremities

  • The patient has a long-standing history of tension (anxiety), gastrointestinal symptoms (upset stomach, diarrhea, heartburn), and a family history of similar symptoms. This suggests a diagnosis of anxiety-related disorder or somatization with physical manifestations.

  • Tingling at extremities (paresthesia) is a common somatic symptom associated with anxiety or panic disorder.

  • Neologisms and hallucinations are features of psychotic disorders, which are not suggested here.

  • Idea of reference is a delusional symptom seen in schizophrenia or related psychotic disorders, which is unlikely given the presentation.

Symptom Association Explanation
Tingling at extremities Anxiety and somatic symptoms Common physical manifestation of anxiety or hyperventilation
Neologisms Psychotic disorders (schizophrenia) Not typical in anxiety or somatic symptom disorders
Hallucinations Psychotic disorders Not present in anxiety disorders
Idea of reference Delusional symptom in schizophrenia Not consistent with anxiety or somatic complaints

 

Neologisms (Option A): Incorrect because neologisms are made-up words seen in schizophrenia, not anxiety disorders.

Hallucinations (Option C): Incorrect because hallucinations are not features of anxiety disorders.

Idea of reference (Option D): Incorrect because this is a psychotic symptom not typical in anxiety or somatic symptom disorders.

questions.text:
Which phases of the disaster cycle can be included in the recovery phase (multiple choice)?


	Response
	Rehabilitation
	Mitigation
	Preparedness
questions.solution:
Correct answer: Option A)1 and 2

 

Explanation:

 

Disaster management is a systematic approach using decisions, organizations to implement policies, strategies to lessen the impact of natural or man-made hazards.

 

Disaster management cycle:

 

 

The three fundamental aspects of disaster management:

  1. Disaster impact: Involves disaster response and relief.
  2. Disaster preparedness: It is the proper equipment of the country to manage disasters.
  3. Disaster mitigation: Preventing the hazard from becoming a disaster.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female patient complains of a persistent headache. A CT scan of the head was performed, as shown below. What is the most accurate diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH):

The given image of the NCCT head shows a star of death appearance, which is a characteristic feature of subarachnoid hemorrhage. The structures which appear white are:

  • Interhemispheric fissure
  • Sylvian fissure
  • Suprasellar cistern
  • Peri mesencephalic cistern

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Epidural hemorrhage: EDH typically appears as a biconvex or lentiform shape on a CT scan.

 

Option C - Subdural hemorrhage: SDH usually presents as a crescent-shaped or sickle-shaped hemorrhage.

Option D - Intraparenchymal hemorrhage: Intraparenchymal Hemorrhage will show a hyperdense pathology.

questions.text: Impaired gag reflex is caused by a lesion in which of the following cranial nerves?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - CN IX and X:

  • The sensory supply of the oropharynx is via the glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX), and the motor supply is via the vagus nerve (CN X), so any lesion in these nerves will lead to an impaired gag reflex.

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, B, and D are incorrect, as explained above.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding the image provided?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - EMLA can lead to methemoglobinemia

  • EMLA cream is a topical anesthetic composed of 2.5% lidocaine and 2.5% prilocaine. It can lead to methemoglobinemia.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - EMLA contains ropivacaine and lidocaine:

  • EMLA contains lidocaine and prilocaine, not ropivacaine.

Option C - EMLA contains 5% lignocaine:

  • EMLA contains lidocaine (2.5%) and prilocaine (2.5%).

Option D - EMLA acts within 15 mins:

  • EMLA typically takes about 1.5 to 2 hours to achieve full effect, not just 15 minutes.

questions.text: A heavy lifter presents with lower back ache. Identify the nerve compressed in the following disc prolapse?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - L5:

  • This is the most common nerve root affected in disc prolapse, particularly in individuals who lift heavy weights. The L5 nerve root can be compressed by a prolapsed disc, leading to lower back pain, pain radiating down the posterior thigh, lateral aspect of the leg, and weakness in dorsiflexion of the foot (difficulty lifting the foot).

Incorrect Options:

Option A - L4:

  • A disc prolapse affecting the L4 nerve root is less common. Compression at this level can cause symptoms such as pain and weakness in the anterior thigh and knee area, but typically, lower back pain from heavy lifting is more often associated with the L5 or S1 nerve roots.

Option C - S1:

  • Although the S1 nerve root can also be affected by disc prolapse, it typically results in pain and weakness in the posterior leg and plantar aspect of the foot. The S1 nerve root compression is less common in heavy lifters compared to L5.

Option D - S4:

  • Compression of the S4 nerve root is rare in cases of disc prolapse and is usually associated with issues in the sacral region. Symptoms related to S4 would include pelvic and perineal discomfort, which are not typically caused by heavy lifting.

questions.text: Which of the following is a selective norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor used in the management of ADHD?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B – Reboxetine:

  • Reboxetine is a selective norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor (NRI) used in the management of Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD). However, it is not FDA-approved, so it is not used in India and is currently limited to Europe.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, C, and D are used in the management of ADHD but are not selective norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors.

questions.text: A 23-year-old female with a height of 4 feet has a karyotype, as shown in the image below. Which of the following conditions is the most likely etiology?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: A) Turner syndrome

Explanation:

The given karyotype shows an absence of the Y chromosome and monosomy of the X chromosome, which is seen in Turner syndrome.

Turner's Syndrome

  • Pathogenesis: Either 45 X0 (deleted) or 46 Xr(X) (Ring Chromosome)
  • In Turner's Syndrome, the IQ is normal.
  • Patients with higher webbing of the neck have higher chances of cardiac symptoms.
  • Clinical features:

Incorrect Options:

Klinefelter syndrome (Option B): In Klinefelter syndrome, an extra X chromosome is present.

Mayer-Rokitansky-Küster-Hauser syndrome (MRKHS) (Option C): Mayer-Rokitansky-Küster-Hauser syndrome is characterized by the failure of the uterus and the vagina to develop properly in women who have normal ovarian function and normal external genitalia.

Edwards syndrome (Option D): In Edwards syndrome, there is trisomy of chromosome 18.

questions.text: A patient with prolonged intubation complained of respiratory distress. Which of the following staging systems is used to stage the condition shown in the image?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Cotton-Meyer classification:

  • The Cottom-Meyer classification is specifically designed to stage laryngotracheal stenosis, particularly the narrowing of the airway after intubation or tracheostomy. It grades the stenosis based on the percentage of the lumen that is narrowed.

Incorrect Options:

  • Options B, C, and D are not used to classify subglottic stenosis.

questions.text: Calculate the median of the following data set: 2, 3, 4, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8.
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - 4.5:

  • The median is the middle value of an ordered data set. Since there are 8 numbers, the median is the average of the 4th and 5th numbers (4 and 5). Thus, the median is (4 + 5) / 2 = 4.5.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, C and D are incorrect as given above.

questions.text: In medicolegal examination accused 18 year old male claims he is 16 year old. Which joint x-ray should be done?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Knee and wrist:

Knee and wrist X-rays are commonly used to assess skeletal maturity and bone age in medico-legal examinations. These joints are particularly useful for evaluating the maturity of the bones and growth plates, which helps in estimating the chronological age of an individual. The epiphyseal ossification patterns in the knee and wrist are well-documented and reliable indicators of skeletal age.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Head & shoulder:

X-rays of the head and shoulder are less useful for determining bone age because the skeletal maturity indicators are less distinct in these regions compared to the knee and wrist.

Option B - Elbow and ankle:

While the elbow and ankle can provide some information on bone age, they are not as commonly used or as reliable as the knee and wrist for this purpose. The elbow and ankle are not as definitive in assessing the maturity of growth plates.

Option D - Elbow & hip:

The elbow and hip can be used to assess bone age, but they are not as commonly employed as the knee and wrist. The hip is less frequently used for this purpose because of variability in ossification patterns.

questions.text: Identify the arrow marked nerve:
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Medial pectoral nerve:

  • The medial pectoral nerve arises from the medial cord of the brachial plexus and innervates the pectoralis minor and part of the pectoralis major muscles. The nerve typically pierces the pectoralis minor before reaching the pectoralis major. In an anatomical image or dissection, the medial pectoral nerve can be identified as the nerve that passes through or near the pectoralis minor and then continues to supply the pectoralis major.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Lateral Pectoral Nerve:

  • The lateral pectoral nerve arises from the lateral cord of the brachial plexus and primarily innervates the pectoralis major muscle. Unlike the medial pectoral nerve, it does not pierce the pectoralis minor but rather passes above it. The lateral pectoral nerve is generally found more laterally and superiorly than the medial pectoral nerve.

Option C - Long Thoracic Nerve:

  • The long thoracic nerve innervates the serratus anterior muscle. It runs down the side of the thorax and can be seen on the surface of the serratus anterior. It is not associated with the pectoral muscles and is positioned more posteriorly and laterally compared to the pectoral nerves.

Option D - Thoracodorsal Nerve:

  • The thoracodorsal nerve arises from the posterior cord of the brachial plexus and innervates the latissimus dorsi muscle. It is found on the posterior side of the thorax and is not involved with the pectoral muscles, making it distinct from the medial pectoral nerve.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is appropriate for treating a 75-year-old woman with urinary incontinence triggered by stress, such as coughing?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Tolterodine:

  • Mechanism of Action: Tolterodine is an antimuscarinic agent that specifically targets muscarinic receptors in the bladder. It reduces involuntary bladder contractions by blocking these receptors, which can help in managing symptoms of urinary incontinence, particularly urge incontinence.
  • Use in Stress Incontinence: While tolterodine is primarily used to treat urge incontinence, it can sometimes be beneficial in mixed incontinence cases where urgency is also a factor. However, the first-line treatment for pure stress incontinence typically involves non-pharmacological approaches like pelvic floor exercises. Pharmacologically, stress incontinence is less commonly treated with medications, but if there is an urgency component, tolterodine may be considered.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Ipratropium:

  • Mechanism of Action: Ipratropium is an anticholinergic drug used mainly as a bronchodilator in the treatment of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and asthma. It has no role in the management of urinary incontinence.

Option C - Telenzepine:

  • Mechanism of Action: Telenzepine is a selective M1 muscarinic receptor antagonist used mainly for reducing gastric acid secretion in conditions like peptic ulcer disease. It is not indicated for treating urinary incontinence.

Option D - Tropicamide:

  • Mechanism of Action: Tropicamide is an antimuscarinic drug used primarily as a mydriatic agent to dilate the pupil for ophthalmic examinations. It has no effect on bladder function and is not used for urinary incontinence.

questions.text: A patient presents with perianal itching. A perianal swab was taken, and the image below shows the findings. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Enterobius vermicularis:

  • Enterobius vermicularis (pinworm) causes perianal itching, particularly at night, due to the female worm laying eggs around the anus. Diagnosis is typically made by identifying the characteristic D-shaped eggs using the scotch tape test or NIH swab.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Hymenolepis nana: The dwarf tapeworm typically causes abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea but not perianal itching.

Options B and D - Ancylostoma and Necator americanus: Ancylostoma, now known as Necator americanus, is a hookworm that primarily causes iron deficiency anemia, ground itch, and creeping eruption.

questions.text: A 62-year-old patient presents with left-sided arm and leg weakness, right-sided facial paralysis, and difficulty with horizontal eye movements. Based on the clinical presentation, which of the following syndromes is most consistent with these symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Millard-Gubler syndrome:

  • Millard-Gubler syndrome, also known as ventral pontine syndrome, is characterized by a combination of ipsilateral cranial nerve (CN) VI and VII palsy with contralateral hemiplegia. The clinical presentation in this case—left-sided arm and leg weakness (contralateral hemiplegia), right-sided facial paralysis (ipsilateral CN VII palsy), and difficulty with horizontal eye movements (ipsilateral CN VI palsy)—is consistent with Millard-Gubler syndrome.
  • This syndrome occurs due to a lesion in the ventral pons, affecting the corticospinal tract (which causes contralateral hemiplegia) and the fascicles of the abducens (CN VI) and facial (CN VII) nerves, leading to ipsilateral facial paralysis and difficulty in horizontal eye movements.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Foville syndrome: This syndrome also involves a lesion in the pons, but it typically affects the paramedian region, leading to ipsilateral facial paralysis, horizontal gaze palsy, and contralateral hemiplegia. However, Foville syndrome often includes additional symptoms like loss of conjugate gaze due to involvement of the pontine tegmentum.

Option B - Benedict's syndrome: This syndrome is caused by a lesion in the midbrain, involving the red nucleus and the third nerve fascicles. It leads to ipsilateral oculomotor nerve palsy (ptosis, dilated pupil, and loss of most eye movements) and contralateral ataxia and tremor. It does not match the symptomatology of the case described.

Option D - Wallenberg syndrome: Also known as lateral medullary syndrome, this condition is due to a lesion in the lateral part of the medulla oblongata. It results in ipsilateral facial pain and temperature sensation loss, contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation on the body, dysphagia, hoarseness, and vertigo. It does not involve cranial nerves VI and VII or cause contralateral hemiplegia.

questions.text: The formula with the numerator being maternal deaths and the denominator being women of reproductive age represents which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Maternal mortality rate:

  • The maternal mortality rate (MMRate) is calculated as the number of maternal deaths per 100,000 women of reproductive age (usually defined as ages 15-49) in a given time period. It measures the risk of maternal death in the general population of women of reproductive age.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Maternal mortality ratio: This ratio measures the number of maternal deaths per 100,000 live births in a given time period. It reflects the risk of death once a woman becomes pregnant, not the general population risk.

Option C - Perinatal mortality rate: This rate measures the number of stillbirths and deaths within the first week of life per 1,000 total births (live births plus stillbirths). It does not relate to maternal deaths.

Option D - Perinatal mortality ratio: This term is not commonly used. If used, it might be mistaken for the perinatal mortality rate, but it does not apply to maternal deaths or reproductive-age women.

questions.text: A patient of CKD has tachycardia. An ECG is taken and shown below. What’s the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Hyperkalemia:

  • Chronic kidney disease (CKD) often leads to electrolyte imbalances due to impaired kidney function. Hyperkalemia is one such common imbalance, which can have significant effects on cardiac function.

  • ECG Findings in Hyperkalemia:

    • Tall, peaked T waves

    • Widened QRS complexes

    • Prolonged PR interval

    • Flattening or absence of P waves

    • Eventually, this can lead to a sine-wave pattern and ventricular fibrillation if untreated.

  • These ECG changes are characteristic of hyperkalemia, particularly in the setting of CKD, where the kidneys are unable to excrete potassium effectively.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Hypokalemia: ECG findings typically include U waves, flattened or inverted T waves, and prolonged QT interval.

Option C - Hypercalcemia: ECG may show a shortened QT interval.

Option D - Hypocalcemia: ECG may show a prolonged QT interval.

questions.text: A pregnant female at 37 weeks of gestation presents for a routine antenatal checkup. She is currently on warfarin. What would be the next step?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Switch to LMWH:

  • Warfarin is contraindicated in the later stages of pregnancy due to the risk of fetal complications and bleeding during delivery.
  • Low Molecular Weight Heparin (LMWH) is safer for use in pregnancy as it does not cross the placenta and reduces the risk of bleeding.
  • At 37 weeks, switching from warfarin to LMWH is the recommended step to ensure safety during the upcoming delivery.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Immediate induction:

  • Induction at 37 weeks without managing the anticoagulation could pose significant risks due to potential bleeding complications.
  • Anticoagulation should be carefully managed before considering induction, making this option inappropriate as the first step.

Option C - LSCS (Lower Segment Caesarean Section):

  • An elective caesarean section would require careful planning, including discontinuing warfarin and possibly switching to LMWH beforehand to manage bleeding risks.
  • However, LSCS is not the immediate next step without addressing anticoagulation.

Option D - Continue the same:

  • Continuing warfarin is not recommended at this stage of pregnancy due to the increased risk of fetal bleeding and complications during delivery.
  • Thus, this is not the correct approach.

questions.text: Police brought a person from the railway track with features of dry dilated pupil, dry skin , slurring of speech , altered sensorium. The poisoning is?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Datura:

Datura is a plant known for its anticholinergic properties. It can cause symptoms of anticholinergic toxicity, which include dry skin, dilated pupils (mydriasis), slurred speech, and altered sensorium. This is consistent with the clinical presentation described.

 

Incorrect Options

Option A - Morphine:
Morphine is an opioid and typically causes miosis (constricted pupils), not mydriasis. It can lead to respiratory depression and altered sensorium, but the dry skin and dilated pupils are not characteristic of morphine poisoning.

Option B - Cannabis:
Cannabis can cause altered sensorium and slurred speech but is not associated with dry skin or dilated pupils. Cannabis effects are typically less severe and do not match the full clinical picture described.

Option D - Alcohol:
Alcohol can cause altered sensorium and slurred speech, but it is not associated with dry skin or dilated pupils. Alcohol typically causes miosis and does not have the anticholinergic effects seen with Datura.

questions.text: Behind the medial malleolus and in front of Achilles which artery is present?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Posterior tibial artery:

  • Posterior tibial artery: The posterior tibial artery is located behind the medial malleolus and in front of the Achilles tendon. It runs posterior to the medial malleolus and can be palpated in this region.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Peroneal artery: The peroneal artery (also known as the fibular artery) is located along the lateral side of the leg and is not found behind the medial malleolus. It supplies the lateral compartment of the leg.

Option C - Anterior tibial artery: The anterior tibial artery runs down the anterior part of the leg, in front of the interosseous membrane, and becomes the dorsalis pedis artery at the ankle. It is not located behind the medial malleolus.

Option D - Dorsalis pedis artery: The dorsalis pedis artery is located on the dorsum (top) of the foot, not behind the medial malleolus.

questions.text: A patient with multiple tendon xanthomas is found to have a serum cholesterol level of 398 mg/dL and an LDL level of 220 mg/dL. What is the most likely defect?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - LDL receptor defect:

  • The most likely defect in a patient with multiple tendon xanthomas, elevated serum cholesterol levels, and LDL levels is an LDL receptor defect. LDL levels in the blood remain high because the liver and other cells cannot efficiently remove LDL from the bloodstream. This leads to elevated cholesterol levels and the formation of xanthomas due to the accumulation of cholesterol in tissues.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, C, and D do not present with the given findings.

questions.text: A child was born after 8 months of father's death. Grandparents filed a case that the baby is not their son's. DNA is positive. The child is called ?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Posthumous child:

A posthumous child is one who is born after the death of one or both parents. In this case, since the child was born after the father's death but is confirmed by DNA to be the biological child of the deceased father, the correct term is "posthumous child."

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Suppositious child:
A suppositious child refers to a child who is falsely claimed to be the legitimate child of a deceased person, but this term is not commonly used in modern legal or medical contexts. It does not apply to the situation described.

Option B - Fabricated child:
A fabricated child is not a standard term used in legal or medical contexts. It suggests falsification but is not relevant in the context of a child's legitimacy or paternity.

Option D - Illegitimate child:
An illegitimate child is one born out of wedlock. However, since the issue in this case is related to the timing of birth relative to the father's death rather than marital status, "illegitimate child" is not the most accurate term here.

questions.text: A 2-month-old child is brought to the ophthalmology OPD with the following presentation. What is the ideal management?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Operate immediately:

  • In this situation, the image reveals bilateral congenital cataracts, meaning both eyes are affected. If not treated promptly, this condition can result in irreversible vision loss due to amblyopia. For bilateral cataracts, surgery is typically performed after the child reaches one month of age, so immediate surgery is necessary in this case.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, C, and D are incorrect, as explained above.

questions.text: An 8-year-old male child presents with fever and tenderness in the left lower limb. The limb is warm to the touch, and ESR is raised. An X-ray reveals periosteal elevation. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Osteomyelitis is an infection of the bone, which typically presents with fever, localized pain, warmth, and tenderness. Raised ESR and periosteal elevation on X-ray are classic findings. The history of fever along with these findings makes osteomyelitis the most likely diagnosis in this case.

Investigations of Acute Osteomyelitis

 

  • X-ray
    • Normal during the 1st week.
    • z (periosteal reaction) by 7-10 days.
      • Classical X-ray sign of acute pyogenic osteomyelitis.
    • Later signs
      • Periosteal thickening becomes more obvious.
      • Patchy rarefaction of the metaphysis is observed.
      • Ragged features of bone destruction appear.
    • Important late sign
      • Regional Osteoporosis -metabolically active living bone.
      • The segment that does not become osteoporotic is metabolically inactive and may be dead.

 

Osteomyelitis of the Tibia

 

  • MRI
    • Most sensitive even in the early phase.
    • Detects bone marrow oedema in osteomyelitis within 24 hours
    • The best method of demonstrating bone marrow inflammation.
  • Radio scintigraphy with Gallium citrate - highly sensitive but less specific.
  • SPECT/CT imaging
    • Offers better anatomical localization and a more accurate definition of infection extent compared to conventional planar studies and SPECT alone.
    • It effectively differentiates between soft tissue and bone infections, assesses suspected infected sites with structural bone changes, and clearly defines infective foci in complex anatomical areas.
  • Aspiration of pus-
    • Confirmation of the diagnosis.
    • Aspirate from the metaphyseal subperiosteal abscess, extraosseous soft tissues, or an adjacent joint using a 16- or 18-gauge trocar needle.
    • Even if no pus is present, send a smear of the aspirate for microbiological examination and antibiotic sensitivity testing.

 

Ewing Sarcoma (Option A) is a malignant bone tumor common in children and adolescents. It often presents with pain and swelling, sometimes accompanied by fever

Osteosarcoma (Option B) is a malignant bone tumor that occurs primarily in adolescents. It presents with localized pain and swelling, and X-rays often show a "sunburst" pattern and Codman's triangle.

Giant Cell Tumor (GCT) (Option D) is a benign but locally aggressive bone tumor that typically occurs near the ends of long bones in young adults. It is rare in children and usually does not present with systemic symptoms like fever and periosteal elevation.

questions.text: Identify the stage of disease given in the image.
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Type 2:

  • The cyst becomes more complex, often with the presence of daughter cysts, membranes, or debris. The cyst wall may show signs of rupture or detachment.
  • Imaging Characteristics: A mixed pattern with daughter cysts, floating membranes ("water lily sign"), or internal debris. This stage indicates an ongoing degenerative process of the cyst, with possible partial rupture.

 

WHO-IWGE staging

Gharbi classification

Description

Stage

CE1

Type I

Unilocular anechoic cystic lesion with double line sign

Active

CE2

Type III

Multiseptated, "rosette-like" "honeycomb" cyst

Active

CE3 A

Type II

Cyst with detached membranes (water-lily sign)

Transitional

CE3 B

Type III

Cyst with daughter cysts in solid matrix

Transitional

CE4

Type IV

Cyst with heterogenous hypoechoic/hyperechoic contents. No daughter cysts

Inactive

CE5

Type V

Solid cyst with calcified wall

Inactive

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Type 1:

  • The cyst is small and filled with clear fluid, with no visible daughter cysts or debris. This represents the early, uncomplicated stage.
  • Imaging Characteristics: A purely cystic lesion with smooth walls, no internal septations, or calcifications.

Option C - Type 3:

  • The cyst begins to mature, showing internal septations or a "honeycomb" appearance as daughter cysts start forming within the main cyst.
  • Imaging Characteristics: Multiple small cysts within the main cyst, leading to a multilocular appearance. The cyst walls remain intact, and the fluid is still clear.

Option D - Type 4:

  • The cyst shows evidence of complete degeneration, with a solidified appearance. The cyst is often calcified and may no longer be active.
  • Imaging Characteristics: A dense, calcified mass with no visible fluid or daughter cysts. The cyst is inactive or dead.

questions.text: What is the inclusion criterion for starting bedaquiline in a patient presenting with multidrug-resistant (MDR) or rifampicin-resistant (RR) tuberculosis?

choices.text: Resistance to both rifampicin and isoniazid with mutations in the inhA and katG genes
Resistance to rifampicin but sensitivity to fluoroquinolones
Resistance to rifampicin and sensitivity to isoniazid
Resistance to both rifampicin and fluoroquinolones

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Resistance to Both Rifampicin and Isoniazid with Mutations in the inhA and katG Genes:

  • Bedaquiline is typically used for treating multidrug-resistant (MDR) tuberculosis, which includes cases with resistance to both rifampicin and isoniazid. This includes strains with mutations in the inhA and katG genes, which are associated with isoniazid resistance. Bedaquiline is considered in such cases when other second-line drugs are not effective or suitable, providing a vital treatment option for MDR-TB.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Resistance to Rifampicin but Sensitivity to Fluoroquinolones:

  • While resistance to rifampicin is a key factor in MDR-TB, the inclusion criterion for starting bedaquiline is more specific. Sensitivity to fluoroquinolones alone does not meet the criteria for bedaquiline use; it is usually considered in the broader context of multidrug-resistant TB, including resistance to both rifampicin and isoniazid.

Option C - Resistance to Rifampicin and Sensitivity to Isoniazid:

  • Resistance to rifampicin and sensitivity to isoniazid would be classified as rifampicin-resistant TB rather than MDR-TB. Bedaquiline is typically used for MDR-TB, which involves resistance to both rifampicin and isoniazid, not just one.

Option D - Resistance to Both Rifampicin and Fluoroquinolones:

  • Resistance to both rifampicin and fluoroquinolones suggests a more severe form of drug-resistant TB, potentially extensively drug-resistant (XDR-TB). Bedaquiline may still be used in such cases, but the initial criterion for starting it is based on MDR-TB, which includes resistance to both rifampicin and isoniazid.

questions.text: A 14-year-old child with a history of recurrent bleeding undergoes an endoscopic examination, which is given below. What is the investigation of choice (IOC) for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Contrast-Enhanced CT (CECT):

  • The image shows a globular pink mass in the posterior part of the nasal cavity, and the septum is being pushed to the opposite side. These findings are suggestive of juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma, and the investigation of choice is a CECT scan

Incorrect Options:

  • Options B, C and D are not the IOC for JNAF.

questions.text: Endoscopic image show following finding what is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Esophageal varices:

  • Esophageal varices are dilated submucosal veins in the esophagus, typically seen in patients with portal hypertension, often due to liver cirrhosis. Endoscopically, they appear as prominent, tortuous veins along the esophageal wall, which is the key feature in the described image.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Barrett’s esophagus: Barrett’s esophagus is characterized by the replacement of normal esophageal squamous epithelium with columnar epithelium due to chronic gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD). Endoscopically, it appears as salmon-colored mucosa extending upward from the gastroesophageal junction. It does not present with dilated veins.

Option C - Gastric erosion: Gastric erosions are superficial mucosal defects in the stomach lining. They may appear as small, shallow ulcers or red, inflamed areas during endoscopy, usually in the gastric mucosa, not the esophagus.

Option D - Chronic GERD: Chronic GERD leads to mucosal changes in the esophagus, such as erosive esophagitis, strictures, or Barrett’s esophagus. However, it does not cause the appearance of dilated veins seen with esophageal varices.

questions.text: Chelator contraindicated in Iron poisoning?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - British Anti-Lewisite (BAL):

  • Mechanism of Action: BAL (dimercaprol) is a chelator primarily used for the treatment of heavy metal poisoning, specifically arsenic, mercury, and lead.
  • Use in Iron Poisoning: BAL is contraindicated in iron poisoning because it is not effective for iron and can potentially displace iron from its chelation sites, worsening the situation. It does not effectively bind iron and could potentially complicate the clinical picture in iron toxicity.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Calcium Disodium EDTA:

  • Mechanism of Action: Calcium disodium EDTA (ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid) is a chelator used for lead poisoning and other heavy metals. While it is not the first choice for iron poisoning, it is used in some cases of iron overload to a limited extent.
  • Use in Iron Poisoning: Calcium disodium EDTA is not typically used for iron poisoning, but it is not contraindicated. It is more commonly used for lead and other heavy metal poisonings.

Option B - Deferoxamine:

  • Mechanism of Action: Deferoxamine is a specific iron chelator that binds to free iron in the bloodstream and facilitates its excretion.
  • Use in Iron Poisoning: Deferoxamine is the drug of choice for treating iron poisoning. It is effective in removing excess iron from the body and is specifically indicated for iron overload conditions.

Option D - Penicillamine:

  • Mechanism of Action: Penicillamine is a chelator used primarily for copper poisoning (e.g., Wilson's disease) and can also be used for lead poisoning.
  • Use in Iron Poisoning: Penicillamine is generally not used for iron poisoning, but it is not contraindicated. It is less effective compared to deferoxamine for iron overload and is not the first choice.

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis for a G2P1L1 woman with a history of hysterectomy?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: A) Placenta accreta

Explanation:

  • Placenta accreta is a condition where the placenta attaches too deeply to the uterine wall and does not separate easily after delivery.
  • In women who have undergone a hysterectomy, the abnormal attachment of the placenta(In the image) may occur if there is retained uterine tissue or during a planned cesarean section where a partial uterus remains. This makes placenta accreta the most likely diagnosis in this scenario.

 

Incorrect Options:

(Option B) Placenta inversion:

  • Placenta inversion occurs when the placenta detaches and pulls the uterus inside-out during delivery. This is a rare but serious complication often associated with excessive traction on the umbilical cord. It is not typically related to a history of hysterectomy and is therefore less likely in this case.

(Option C) Placenta abruption:

  • Placenta abruption involves the premature separation of the placenta from the uterus, leading to bleeding and potential complications for both mother and fetus. While placenta abruption is an obstetric emergency, it is not directly linked to a history of hysterectomy and does not fit the clinical context provided.

(Option D) Placenta previa:

Placenta previa occurs when the placenta covers the cervix, causing bleeding in the latter part of pregnancy. It is more common in women with a history of cesarean sections but is not typically associated with a hysterectomy. Additionally, placenta previa is usually diagnosed via ultrasound before delivery and does not directly explain the clinical scenario of a woman with a hysterectomy.

questions.text: Patient present with large sweaty hands, macroglossia and frontal bossing. Select the best test for confirmation of the diagnosis:
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - GH levels after glucose suppression:

  • The best test for confirming a diagnosis of acromegaly (often caused by excess growth hormone) is GH suppression test. 
  • 75g of oral glucose is administered and blood GH levels are checked at 30, 60, 90, and 120 minutes. Normally, glucose suppressess GH, If GH > 1ng/ml, it is confirmatory of acromegaly.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - GHRH levels: Growth Hormone-Releasing Hormone (GHRH) levels are not typically used for the diagnosis of acromegaly. While GHRH can stimulate growth hormone release, its levels are not directly indicative of acromegaly.

Option C - IGF-2: IGF-2 is not typically used for diagnosing acromegaly. It is more relevant in conditions like certain tumors and is not a primary diagnostic marker for acromegaly.

Option B - Insulin-like Growth Factor 1 (IGF-1). IGF-1 levels are elevated in acromegaly due to the increased secretion of growth hormone. IGF-1 is a stable marker that reflects chronic exposure to growth hormone and is therefore used as the screening test for acromegaly.

questions.text: A patient presents with a gradual loss of night vision and peripheral vision. What is the most likely diagnosis based on fundoscopy findings?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Retinitis pigmentosa:

The patient’s presentation and presence of bony spicules, pale waxy disc, and attenuated arteries are suggestive of retinitis pigmentosa.

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C, and D do not exhibit the fundoscopy findings given in the question.

questions.text: Which disease is commonly referred to as "Desert Rheumatism"?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Coccidomycosis:

  • Coccidioidomycosis, also known as "Valley fever" or "Desert rheumatism," is a fungal infection caused by Coccidioides immitis. It is commonly found in desert regions and can cause joint pain, hence the name "Desert Rheumatism."

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options B, C, and D are not referred to as Desert Rheumatism.

questions.text: Which classification is used for the following fracture, and what is its stage?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Gartland 3:

  • The Gartland classification is specifically used for supracondylar fractures of the humerus in children. A Gartland type 3 fracture is characterized by complete displacement of the fracture with no cortical contact between the fragments. This type of fracture is unstable and often requires surgical intervention.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Gartland 2:

  • This is also part of the Gartland classification, describing a supracondylar fracture where there is partial displacement, but some cortical contact is still maintained. It is less severe than Gartland 3.

Option C - Salter-Harris 3:

  • The Salter-Harris classification is used for physeal (growth plate) fractures, not supracondylar fractures. A type 3 fracture involves a fracture through the growth plate and the epiphysis, extending into the joint.

Option D - Salter-Harris 2:

  • This classification describes a fracture through the growth plate and metaphysis, sparing the epiphysis. Like option C, it is not relevant to supracondylar fractures of the humerus.

questions.text: What is the correct order of disaster management steps?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A: Impact - Response - Rehab - Mitigation

  • Impact: Refers to the immediate consequences of the disaster.
  • Response: Actions taken to address the immediate needs and mitigate further damage.
  • Rehab: Short for rehabilitation, involving recovery efforts and rebuilding.
  • Mitigation: Long-term strategies to reduce the risk of future disasters.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Option B, C and D are incorrect as given above.

questions.text: Which muscle is implicated in ptosis in Horner syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Müller muscle:

  • Ptosis in Horner syndrome is due to the paralysis of the Müller's muscle, a smooth muscle responsible for a minor portion of upper eyelid retraction.

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C, and D are not responsible for causing ptosis in Horner’s syndrome.

questions.text: A patient with a history of Wilson's disease presents with neurological manifestations. Which of the following is the best diagnostic modality?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Hepatic parenchymal demonstration of copper:

  • Wilson's disease is a genetic disorder characterized by excessive accumulation of copper in various body tissues, primarily the liver and brain. The best diagnostic modality to confirm Wilson's disease, especially in the presence of neurological manifestations, is hepatic parenchymal demonstration of copper. This is usually done by performing a liver biopsy to measure the hepatic copper concentration, which is considered the gold standard for diagnosis.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Serum ceruloplasmin: While serum ceruloplasmin is often low in Wilson's disease, it is not the most reliable diagnostic tool, as ceruloplasmin levels can be low in other conditions and may be normal in some patients with Wilson's disease.

Option B - Urinary copper excretion: This test measures 24-hour urinary copper excretion and is elevated in Wilson's disease, but it is not as definitive as hepatic copper measurement. It is useful as part of the diagnostic workup but not the best single test.

Option D - Anti-tissue transglutaminase (Anti-tTG) antibody: This antibody is associated with celiac disease and is not relevant to the diagnosis of Wilson's disease.

questions.text: Based on the provided chest X-ray, which of the following procedures would be most challenging to perform?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Tracheostomy:

  • The given image shows the deviation of the trachea towards the right side, which will make it very difficult to perform a tracheostomy.

Incorrect Options:

  • Options B, C, and D are not difficult to perform in a patient with a deviated trachea.

questions.text: A patient presents with an umbilical hernia that was previously reducible but has now become irreducible. Which of the following is the most appropriate management option?
questions.solution:
Correct A - Umbilical excision:
