Option B - McNemar test: This test is used for paired nominal data, specifically to analyze the difference in proportions for matched pairs, such as yes/no responses before and after an intervention. It is not appropriate for comparing means.

Option C - Chi-square test: The chi-square test is used to analyze categorical data to determine if there is a significant association between variables. It is not suitable for comparing means, especially when dealing with continuous data like cholesterol levels.

Option D - Wilcoxon signed-rank test: This is a non-parametric test used to compare two related samples or repeated measurements on a single sample when the data does not follow a normal distribution. It is an alternative to the paired t-test when the data is not normally distributed.

questions.text: Identify the structure marked with the arrow in the diagram provided:
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Sebaceous gland:

  • The structure marked with an arrow shows a gland opening into the hair follicle, which is a sebaceous gland.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, C, and D are not marked in the given image.

questions.text: A female presents at 22 weeks of pregnancy due to rape. Which statement is correct regarding medical termination of pregnancy (MTP)?

choices.text: Between 20-24 weeks, one doctor’s opinion is required
Between 20-24 weeks, MTP is only done if it is life-saving for the mother
MTP can be done up to 24 weeks in this case
MTP can be done after 24 weeks.

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - MTP can be done up to 24 weeks in this case:

  • MTP can be done up to 24 weeks in this case:
    • According to the amended MTP Act, 2021, MTP is permitted up to 24 weeks in cases of rape, with the opinion of two doctors.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Between 20-24 weeks, one doctor’s opinion is required: Under the Medical Termination of Pregnancy (Amendment) Act, 2021, for pregnancies between 20-24 weeks, the opinion of two doctors is required, not just one. This applies to specific categories, including survivors of sexual assault.

Option B - Between 20-24 weeks, MTP is only done if it is life-saving for the mother: While protecting the life of the mother is one consideration, MTP can also be performed during this period for other reasons, including if the pregnancy is a result of rape, or if there are significant fetal anomalies, without the need for the condition to be life-threatening to the mother.

Option D - MTP can be done after 24 weeks: MTP beyond 24 weeks is generally not permitted unless severe fetal anomalies are detected that are incompatible with life, or if there is a threat to the mother's life or health. This requires the approval of a medical board.

questions.text: A 7-year-old male child presents with a history of recurrent urinary tract infections, poor urinary stream, and failure to thrive. On examination, his abdomen is distended, and there is a palpable bladder. His MCU is given below. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Cystoscopic resection:

  • Cystoscopic resection is the treatment of choice for Posterior Urethral Valve (PUV), which is a congenital condition characterized by abnormal valve-like folds in the posterior urethra, leading to urinary obstruction.

 

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C, and D are not appropriate for initial management of PUV.

questions.text: A patient presents with 5th metatarsal fracture. For how many days he/she would have to wear cast?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - 6-8 weeks:

  • This is the typical duration for casting a 5th metatarsal fracture. It allows adequate time for bone healing, considering the location and nature of the fracture. This duration helps ensure proper alignment and support, leading to better outcomes.

 

Incorrect Options

Options A,B and D are incorrect as given above

questions.text: Which of the following is an indication for adjuvant radiotherapy in oral malignancy after resection and modified radical neck dissection (MRND)?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Extranodal extension: Extranodal extension (ENE) is a strong indication for adjuvant radiotherapy because it signifies a higher risk of local recurrence and poorer prognosis. ENE occurs when cancer extends beyond the lymph node capsule into surrounding tissues.It is major criterion for RT

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Multiple lymph node metastasis:

  • Multiple lymph node metastases (particularly when there are three or more positive nodes) significantly increase the risk of recurrence, making adjuvant radiotherapy necessary to improve local control and overall survival. But ENE has the highest risk  and priority for adjuvant RT

Option C - T3 tumor: A T3 tumor, which indicates a large primary tumor or one that invades adjacent structures, is a high-risk factor. While it may warrant adjuvant radiotherapy, it is not as definitive an indication as  ENE.

Option D - Close margin: A close margin, typically defined as less than 5 mm between the tumor and the resection edge, often leads to consideration for adjuvant therapy. However, it is not as strong an indication as multiple lymph node metastases or ENE, and decisions are often made case-by-case depending on other factors.

questions.text: Which of the following diseases has the maximum submerged portion of the iceberg?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Influenza:

  • Influenza has the maximum submerged portion of the iceberg because a large number of infected individuals may be asymptomatic or exhibit mild symptoms, resulting in underreporting and unrecognized cases. This large reservoir of mild or asymptomatic cases contributes significantly to the spread of the disease.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Chickenpox: Like influenza, chickenpox can have a large submerged portion where mild or atypical cases go unreported, especially in individuals with prior immunity or vaccination. However, most cases present with recognizable symptoms like rash.

Option C - Tetanus: Tetanus has a small submerged portion because it generally presents with noticeable and severe symptoms. It does not spread from person to person, so there is no asymptomatic carrier state contributing to its epidemiological iceberg.

Option D - Rabies: Rabies has the least submerged portion of the iceberg because it is almost always symptomatic and progresses to severe outcomes once symptoms appear. Nearly all cases are identified due to the seriousness of the disease.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with symptoms of anemia, depigmented hair, bleeding gums, and diffuse hair loss. Which of the following mineral deficiencies is most likely associated with this clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Copper:

The clinical presentation of anemia, depigmented hair, bleeding gums, and diffuse hair loss is most consistent with copper deficiency. Copper is a vital trace mineral that plays a significant role in various physiological processes, including iron metabolism, melanin production, connective tissue formation, and the functioning of the immune system.

  • Anemia in copper deficiency is due to impaired iron metabolism, leading to iron deficiency anemia.

  • Depigmented hair is a result of decreased melanin production, as copper is a cofactor for the enzyme tyrosinase, which is essential in melanin synthesis.

  • Bleeding gums and diffuse hair loss are linked to impaired collagen synthesis, as copper is necessary for the function of lysyl oxidase, an enzyme involved in the cross-linking of collagen and elastin.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Iron: Iron deficiency commonly leads to anemia and symptoms like fatigue, pallor, and weakness. However, it does not cause depigmented hair, bleeding gums, or diffuse hair loss associated with copper deficiency.

Option C - Fluoride: Fluoride is mainly associated with dental health. Its deficiency can lead to dental caries, but it is not linked to anemia, hair changes, or bleeding gums.

Option D - Zinc: Zinc deficiency can lead to symptoms such as growth retardation, impaired immune function, hair loss, and dermatitis. However, it is not typically associated with depigmented hair, anemia, or bleeding gums, as seen in copper deficiency.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child presents with stable vitals and an ECG showing paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (PSVT). Which of the following is the appropriate treatment?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Adenosine 0.1 mg/kg:

  • This is the correct initial treatment for PSVT in a child with stable vitals. Adenosine is a first-line medication for terminating PSVT by temporarily blocking the AV node, often restoring normal sinus rhythm.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Cardioversion:

  • This is typically reserved for patients with PSVT who are hemodynamically unstable or in cases where pharmacologic treatment is ineffective. Given that the child has stable vitals, cardioversion is not the first-line treatment.

Option B - Adenosine 0.2 mg/kg:

  • This is the dose used if the initial dose of adenosine (0.1 mg/kg) fails to convert the PSVT. It is not the starting dose, so it is not the appropriate initial treatment.

Option D - IV Adrenaline:

  • Adrenaline is not indicated for treating PSVT. It is used in resuscitation protocols, particularly in cases of cardiac arrest or anaphylaxis, not for stable PSVT.

questions.text: Recording of evidence of a female in sexual Assault in court is done in?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Closed court proceedings:

In cases involving sexual assault, closed court proceedings are used to ensure the privacy and protection of the victim. These proceedings are not open to the public, which helps maintain the victim's confidentiality and reduce the emotional impact of the court process. Closed court sessions help protect the victim from public scrutiny and potential re-traumatization.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Open court proceedings:
Open court proceedings are accessible to the public and can expose the victim to unnecessary stress and scrutiny. Such settings do not provide the privacy needed for sensitive cases like sexual assault.

Option C - Hearing on different location:
While a hearing might be conducted from a different location for logistical reasons (e.g., via video link), this is not specifically designed to protect the privacy of the victim in the same way that closed court proceedings do.

Option D - Hearing on camera:
Although on-camera recordings may be used to record testimony, this does not replace the need for closed court proceedings. On-camera recordings are part of the procedure to ensure that evidence is preserved and presented appropriately, but they are generally conducted within the framework of closed court proceedings to ensure the privacy of the victim.

questions.text: A 5-year-old girl was washing her doll with shampoo containing rotenone. Her mother noticed her in unconscious state. Which is inhibited by the above chemical?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - NADH dehydrogenase

  • Rotenone inhibits NADH dehydrogenase.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options B, C, and D are not inhibited by rotenone.

questions.text: Identify the labeling correctly:

choices.text: A- Superior vena cava, B- Ascending aorta, C- Pulmonary trunk, D- Descending aorta
A- Ascending aorta, B- Descending aorta, C- Pulmonary trunk, D- Superior vena cava
A- Ascending aorta, B- Superior vena cava, C- Descending aorta, D- Pulmonary trunk,
A- Ascending aorta, B- Superior Vena Cava, C- Pulmonary trunk, D- Descending aorta

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - A- , B-Ascending aorta , C- Pulmonary trunk, D- Descending aorta:

  • A. Superior vena cava: The superior vena cava is a large vein that carries deoxygenated blood from the upper half of the body to the right atrium of the heart. It is located anterior and slightly to the right of the ascending aorta.

  • B. Ascending aorta:  The ascending aorta arises from the left ventricle of the heart and is the initial portion of the aorta that moves upward before arching.

  • C. Pulmonary Trunk: The pulmonary trunk is the vessel that arises from the right ventricle and bifurcates into the left and right pulmonary arteries, which carry deoxygenated blood to the lungs. It is positioned anterior to the ascending aorta and the superior vena cava.

  • D. Descending Aorta: The descending aorta continues from the aortic arch and runs downwards behind the heart, supplying blood to the lower parts of the body. It is located posterior to the heart and more to the left in the thoracic cavity.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B , C, D incorrectly labels the structures

questions.text: What is the typical time between fertilization and implantation in human reproduction?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - 8 days:

  • Implantation usually occurs around 6 to 10 days after fertilization, with the average being about 8 days. By this time, the embryo has developed into a blastocyst and is ready to implant into the uterine lining.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - 2 days:

  • This is too short for implantation. After fertilization, the zygote undergoes multiple cell divisions and travels through the fallopian tube towards the uterus. At this point, the embryo is still in transit.

Option C - 14 days:

  • By 14 days after fertilization, the embryo should already be implanted, and early pregnancy may be detectable through specific hormonal changes.

Option D -16 days:

  • If implantation has not occurred by this time, the embryo would likely not be viable, as the uterine environment may no longer support implantation.

questions.text: At ovulation, what is released?

choices.text: Secondary oocyte at the end of meiosis I
Secondary oocyte at the end of meiosis II
Primary oocyte at the end of meiosis I
Primary oocyte at the end of meiosis II

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Secondary oocyte at the end of meiosis I :

  • At ovulation, a secondary oocyte is released. This oocyte has completed meiosis I but has not yet completed meiosis II. The secondary oocyte is arrested in metaphase II and will only complete meiosis II if fertilization occurs.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Secondary oocyte at the end of meiosis II:

  • This option is incorrect because the secondary oocyte only completes meiosis II if it is fertilized by a sperm. Therefore, at ovulation, the oocyte is still in metaphase II, not at the end of meiosis II.

Option C - Primary oocyte at the end of meiosis I:

  • This option is incorrect because the primary oocyte completes meiosis I to form the secondary oocyte before ovulation. It is the secondary oocyte, not the primary oocyte, that is released during ovulation.

Option D - Primary oocyte at the end of meiosis II:

  • This option is incorrect because primary oocytes are arrested in prophase I until puberty. The primary oocyte undergoes meiosis I to become a secondary oocyte, which is what is released during ovulation. Meiosis II is not completed unless fertilization occurs.

questions.text: The following instrument is used for the measurement of?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Cooling power air:

  • The above given image shows a KATA thermometer

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B and D: Globe thermometer measures radiant heat and effective temperature

Option C - Humidity: The hygrometer measures air humidity.

questions.text: Given 500 live births, 12 stillbirths, and 9 deaths within the first 7 days, calculate the Early Neonatal Mortality Rate (ENMR).
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - 18:

  • The Early Neonatal Mortality Rate (ENMR) is calculated as the number of deaths of live-born infants within the first 7 days of life per 1000 live births.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options B, C and D are incorrect as given above.

questions.text: A mother comes with her child who has papules on the extensor surfaces of the skin, which resolve with the administration of vitamins A and C and essential amino acids. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Phrynoderma:

  • Phrynoderma is characterized by papular lesions on the extensor surfaces, which can improve with vitamin A supplementation. The resolution of symptoms with the administration of vitamins A and C, along with essential amino acids, is consistent with this diagnosis.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Rickets: This is a condition resulting from vitamin D deficiency, leading to weak and soft bones in children. Symptoms include bone deformities and growth retardation, but it does not typically present with papules on the extensor surfaces.

Option C - Kwashiorkor: This is a form of protein-energy malnutrition characterized by edema, irritability, and skin changes. It usually involves more generalized symptoms of malnutrition rather than isolated papules that resolve with vitamins and amino acids.

Option D - Marasmus: This is another form of severe malnutrition caused by a deficiency in caloric intake, leading to severe weight loss and muscle wasting. It does not present with papules but rather with severe overall wasting.

questions.text: What is the primary purpose of PEEP (Positive End-Expiratory Pressure) in mechanical ventilation?

choices.text: To open alveoli and prevent atelectasis

questions.solution:
Correct Option D – To open alveoli and prevent atelectasis

  • PEEP is used in mechanical ventilation to keep alveoli open at the end of exhalation, preventing them from collapsing (atelectasis). This helps improve oxygenation and maintain lung function, especially in patients with acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) or other conditions leading to alveolar collapse.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B, and C are not the purpose of PEEP.

questions.text: A smoker presents with an oral lesion, as shown in the image below. Which stain is used to identify this pathology?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Supravital stain:

  • The given image shows a laryngeal mass, for which toluidine blue is used for identification, and it is a supravital stain.

 

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C, and D are not used to identify laryngeal mass.

questions.text: Patient presents with features of right heart failure and exhibits a rapid Y descent on cardiac examination. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Constrictive Pericarditis:

  • Constrictive pericarditis is a condition where the pericardium becomes thickened and fibrotic, leading to impaired filling of the heart, particularly the right side. A rapid Y descent on jugular venous pressure (JVP) is a classic finding in constrictive pericarditis, reflecting rapid early diastolic filling of the ventricle due to the rigid pericardium. The patient may present with signs of right heart failure, such as peripheral edema, ascites, and hepatomegaly.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Cardiac Tamponade: Cardiac tamponade typically presents with a blunted or absent Y descent on JVP tracing due to the equalization of pressures during diastole, which restricts ventricular filling. The presence of a rapid Y descent makes cardiac tamponade less likely.

Option C - Pulmonary Hypertension: Pulmonary hypertension can cause right heart failure, but it is not associated with a rapid Y descent on JVP. The JVP findings in pulmonary hypertension are usually more related to elevated pressure rather than specific waveforms like a rapid Y descent.

Option D - Right Ventricular Infarction: Right ventricular infarction can present with signs of right heart failure. However, the JVP typically shows an elevated a-wave or a prominent X descent, not a rapid Y descent.

questions.text: Which of the following antibodies is associated with celiac disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Anti-TTG:

  • Anti-tissue transglutaminase is associated with celiac disease.

 

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C, and D: Anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (ANCA), Anti-Saccharomyces cerevisiae antibodies (ASCA) and Anti-mitochondrial antibody (AMA) are not associated with celiac disease.

questions.text: In the given capnograph, what does the marked area denote?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B – Alveolar Plateau:

  • In a normal capnograph, the marked area represents the alveolar plateau phase. This is the flat part of the capnograph, indicating constant exhalation of CO2.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, C, and D are not marked in the given capnograph.

questions.text: Identify the device shown in the image?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Nasopharyngeal airway:

  • The given image shows a nasopharyngeal airway (NPA) device or "nasal trumpet." It is a hollow plastic or soft rubber tube that can improve oxygenation and ventilation in cases where bag-valve-mask ventilation is ineffective.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Laryngeal Mask Airway (LMA):

Option C - NG tube:

 

Option D - Oropharyngeal tube:

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient with a known case of homocystinuria presents with joint pain and weakness. Which vitamin is required for the treatment?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Vitamin B6:

  • Homocystinuria is often due to a deficiency in the enzyme cystathionine β-synthase, which requires Vitamin B6 as a cofactor. Supplementing with Vitamin B6 can help reduce homocysteine levels and alleviate symptoms like joint pain and weakness.

 

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C, and D are not preferred in the management of this patient.

questions.text: A child presents with chorioretinitis, hydrocephalus, and cerebral calcifications. What is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Toxoplasma:

  • The triad of chorioretinitis, hydrocephalus, and cerebral calcifications is characteristic of congenital toxoplasmosis caused by Toxoplasma gondii.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options B, C, and D do not cause cerebral calcifications.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presents with respiratory distress and a history of recurrent respiratory infections. Based on the radiographs provided, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Congenital pulmonary airway malformation:

  • The echogenic appearance of the lungs on antenatal ultrasound and multiple cysts in the CT scan and X-ray are suggestive of CPAM.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Lung abscess: A lung abscess typically appears on imaging as a thick-walled cavity within the lung, often containing an air-fluid level.

Option C – Pyopneumothorax: Pyopneumothorax will show an air-fluid level, and loss of silhouette with the dome of the diaphragm may be seen.

Option D - Congenital diaphragmatic hernia: CDH occurs when abdominal organs herniate into the thoracic cavity due to a defect in the diaphragm.

questions.text: Sequence of rigor mortis is?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Head to foot:

Rigor mortis, or postmortem rigidity, typically starts in the smaller muscles and progresses to the larger muscle groups. The sequence generally begins with the muscles of the face and neck, followed by the upper limbs, and then extends to the trunk and lower limbs. Therefore, rigor mortis progresses from the head and upper parts of the body downwards towards the feet.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Center to periphery:
Rigor mortis does not progress from the center of the body to the periphery. It starts in the head and moves towards the feet, not the central parts to the outer extremities.

Option C - Foot to head:
Rigor mortis does not start in the feet and move upwards to the head. It starts in the head and progresses downwards towards the feet.

Option D - Simultaneously:
Rigor mortis does not occur simultaneously in all parts of the body. It progresses in a specific sequence, starting with the head and upper body, then moving downwards.

questions.text: A young patient presents to the outpatient department (OPD) with recurrent colicky abdominal pain. Urine examination reveals the presence of red blood cells (RBCs). What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Cystine stone:

  • The presence of benzene-shaped (hexagonal) crystals in the urine, along with RBCs, strongly suggests cystinuria, a genetic disorder that leads to the formation of cystine stones. These stones are rare and are caused by the poor reabsorption of cystine in the kidneys, leading to its crystallization in urine. The recurrent colicky abdominal pain is typical of urolithiasis.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Glomerulonephritis: This condition involves inflammation of the glomeruli in the kidneys and typically presents with hematuria, proteinuria, and sometimes RBC casts, but not with benzene-shaped crystals.

Option B - Oxalate stone: Calcium oxalate stones are common and may present with similar symptoms, but they are characterized by envelope-shaped crystals in the urine, not benzene-shaped crystals.

Option C - Polycystic kidney disease: This genetic disorder leads to the development of multiple cysts in the kidneys and can cause hematuria, hypertension, and renal failure. However, it does not cause the formation of benzene-shaped crystals in the urine.

questions.text: Identify the syndrome associated with the chromosomal pattern shown in the image below:
questions.solution:
Correct Option: B) Prader-Willi syndrome

Explanation:

The given image shows a part of paternal chromosome 15 deleted, which is seen in Prader-Willi syndrome.

Prader Willi Syndrome

In Prader-Willi syndrome, maternal imprinting is done, and paternal deletion happens.

Clinical features:

  • Mental Retardation
  • Short Stature
  • Obesity/hyperphagia (because of an increase in the hormone called Ghrelin)

Incorrect Options:

Angelman syndrome (Option A): In Angelman syndrome, the maternal region of chromosome 15 is deleted.

Rett Syndrome (Option C):

  • Caused by mutation in the MECP2 gene

  • Chromosomal Location: X chromosome (Xq28)

  • Type of Abnormality: Single-gene mutation (not a chromosomal structural abnormality)

Cri du Chat Syndrome (Option D):

  • Cause: Deletion of the short arm of chromosome 5

  • Chromosomal Abnormality: 46,XX or 46,XY, del(5p)

questions.text: Identify the image given?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Sapna Leprosy:

  • This is the correct answer. The "Sapna" campaign is linked to leprosy awareness in India, symbolizing hope and the possibility of a future free from leprosy-related stigma and disease.

 

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Arohi from HIV: This option may refer to a character or campaign related to HIV awareness, but it is not the correct association for the image related to leprosy.

Option C - Meena UNICEF: The Meena campaign, supported by UNICEF, focuses on gender equality and education for girls in South Asia. It is not related to leprosy or the image in question.

questions.text: Identify the gene commonly involved in the carcinoma shown in the image below:
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - BRAF V600:

  • The image shows Orphan Annie's eye nucleus, which is seen in papillary thyroid cancer. It is associated with BRAF V600 mutation.

 

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B, and D are not associated with papillary thyroid cancer.

questions.text: A mother brings her 14-year-old mentally retarded son to the clinic, complaining of joint pain and an irresistible urge for the boy to bite his fingers and lips. Serum uric acid is elevated. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Lesch-Nyhan syndrome:

  • Lesch-Nyhan syndrome is caused by a deficiency of the enzyme hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase (HGPRT). This enzyme is essential for the salvage pathway of purines, and its deficiency leads to the accumulation of uric acid in the body, causing hyperuricemia. The patient also presents with self-mutilating behaviour.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options B, C, and D do not show the given findings.

questions.text: A female patient with a urinary tract infection (UTI) has more than 10^4 colonies of novobiocin-resistant Staphylococcus. What is the appropriate course of action?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Consider UTI:

  • The presence of novobiocin-resistant Staphylococcus (likely Staphylococcus saprophyticus) in significant numbers (>10^4 colonies) suggests a urinary tract infection.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options B, C, and D are incorrect, as explained above.

questions.text: A child presents with failure to pass stools and is diagnosed with Hirschsprung disease. Which among the following layers of the colon will show congenital absence of neurons?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - 2 & 3:

  • In Hirschsprung disease, the congenital absence of neurons is seen in the submucosa (Meissner's plexus, Layer 2) and the muscularis propria (myenteric plexus, Layer 3). This absence leads to the failure of peristalsis and the subsequent inability to pass stools.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, C, and D: Layers 1 and 4 are not affected by Hirschsprung disease.

questions.text: Identify the visual field defect:
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Blind spot enlargement:

The given image shows blind spot enlargement.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Altitudinal defect:

Option B - Roennes nasal step:

Option D - Arcuate scotoma:

questions.text: Which of the following is not a contraindication for External Cephalic Version (ECV)?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C – Primigravida:

  • Primigravida is not a contraindication for External Cephalic Version. The procedure can be performed on first-time mothers as long as there are no other complicating factors.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Placenta previa:

  • Placenta previa is a contraindication for ECV because the placenta covers the cervical os, increasing the risk of severe bleeding if ECV is attempted.

Option B - Twin pregnancy:

  • Twin pregnancy is also a contraindication for ECV due to the increased risk of complications and the difficulty of safely repositioning multiple fetuses.

Option D - PROM (Premature Rupture of Membranes):

  • PROM is a contraindication for ECV because the rupture of membranes increases the risk of cord prolapse, infection, and other complications during the procedure.

questions.text: A patient presents with hypotension, hyponatremia and blackening of the knuckles and perioral area. Which of the following conditions is most likely associated with these symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Addison’s Disease:

  • Addison’s Disease:

    • Symptoms:

      • Hypotension: Due to insufficient cortisol production affecting blood pressure.

      • Hyponatremia: Caused by low aldosterone levels, leading to reduced sodium reabsorption.

      • Hyperpigmentation: Characterized by darkening of the skin, including knuckles and perioral areas, due to increased ACTH levels stimulating melanocytes.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Conn Syndrome: Characterized by primary hyperaldosteronism, which typically leads to hypertension, hypokalemia (low potassium), and metabolic alkalosis, but not usually associated with hyperpigmentation or hyponatremia.

Option B - Cushing’s Syndrome: Results from excess cortisol production and can present with hypertension, hyperglycemia, and hypokalemia. Hyperpigmentation is not a common feature; instead, you might see features such as easy bruising and a “moon facies.”

Option C - Primary ACTH Deficiency: Leads to low cortisol levels but not usually associated with hyperpigmentation. Patients may experience symptoms of adrenal insufficiency, but hyperpigmentation is more characteristic of primary adrenal insufficiency (Addison’s disease) rather than ACTH deficiency.

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient presents with rashes with an orange hue on his body and thickened palms and soles. Based on the histological image given, what is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Pityriasis rubra pilaris:

  • The patient’s presentation with orange-hued rashes, thickened palms and soles, and the histological findings (checkerboard pattern of hyperkeratosis and parakeratosis) are characteristic of Pityriasis Rubra Pilaris (PRP).

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options B, C, and D show a different histopathological pattern.

questions.text: A patient presents to the outpatient department with the following findings. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Limbal dermoid:

  • Limbal dermoids are congenital benign tumors that cause astigmatism, encroachment on the visual axis, and fatty component infiltration into the cornea. They consist of overgrowths of epidermal appendages, connective tissues, skin, fat, sweat glands, lacrimal glands, and neurologic tissues located partly over the cornea and partly over the sclera.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Pterygium: A pterygium is a fibrovascular growth of the conjunctiva that extends onto the cornea.

Option C - Pyogenic granuloma: A pyogenic granuloma is a red, fleshy, vascular lesion that usually arises after trauma or surgery.

Option D - Pinguecula: A pinguecula is a yellowish, slightly raised lesion on the conjunctiva, usually near the limbus.

questions.text: A 34-year-old female presents with low hemoglobin, platelet count of 25,000/mm3, and raised PT and APTT. The peripheral smear image is shown below. Which of the following fusion genes is likely affected?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - PML-RARA:

  • The given image shows faggot cells containing Auer rods, which is a characteristic feature of Acute myeloid leukemia M3. In AML M3, t(15:17) - PML-RARA fusion gene is affected.

 

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C, and D are not affected in AML M3.

questions.text: A child presents with leukocoria and an intraocular mass. Microscopic examination reveals rosettes with scanty cytoplasm, and the mass is positive for synaptophysin and chromogranin. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A – Retinoblastoma:

  • The presence of an intraocular mass in a child with leukocoria is suggestive of retinoblastoma. Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes and Homer Wright rosettes are characteristic histopathological features of retinoblastoma. It is positive for synaptophysin, NSE, and chromogranin.

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C, and D do not align with the features described in the question.

questions.text: A pregnant woman has just delivered a healthy baby via normal delivery. What is the earliest time at which an intrauterine contraceptive device (IUCD) can be inserted?
questions.solution:
Correct Options A - Within 48 hours:

  • An IUCD can be safely inserted within 48 hours postpartum. The IUCD is often inserted after the placenta is delivered.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - After 6 weeks:

  • This is a common time for IUCD insertion if it wasn't done immediately postpartum. After 6 weeks, the uterus has typically returned to its normal size, and the risk of expulsion is lower compared to immediate insertion. However, this is not the earliest time.

Option C - After 3 months:

  • While an IUCD can be inserted at this time, it is not necessary to wait this long. Waiting until 3 months postpartum is usually done only if there are specific concerns, but it is not the earliest time for insertion.

Option D - After 6 months:

  • Like the 3-month option, insertion at 6 months is possible but unnecessarily delayed. At 6 months, many women may be using other contraceptive methods, and the window for the earliest safe insertion has long passed.

questions.text: A 38-year-old patient presents with chest pain and hoarseness of voice for the past month. Based on the radiographic image provided, what is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Saccular aneurysm of the distal arch
Dissecting aneurysm of the arch of the aorta

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Saccular aneurysm of the distal arch:

  • The clinical presentation and radiographic findings of a localized outpouching on the aorta are consistent with a saccular aneurysm of the aortic arch. The patient presents with chest pain and hoarseness of voice, which suggests the involvement of the left recurrent laryngeal nerve—a phenomenon known as Cardiovocal Syndrome (Ortner syndrome).

 

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C, and D are incorrect, as explained above.

questions.text: Patient presents with recurrent lung infections and CXR is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Kartagener syndrome:

  • Kartagener syndrome is characterized by a triad of symptoms: situs inversus (dextrocardia seen on CXR), chronic sinusitis, and bronchiectasis. The recurrent lung infections in this case are consistent with the chronic respiratory issues seen in Kartagener syndrome. The dextrocardia noted in the CXR supports this diagnosis.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Cystic fibrosis: Cystic fibrosis primarily presents with thick, sticky mucus leading to lung infections, pancreatic insufficiency, and other issues. While it causes recurrent lung infections, it is not associated with dextrocardia. The diagnosis is typically supported by sweat chloride tests and genetic testing.

Option C - DiGeorge syndrome: DiGeorge syndrome includes a range of congenital defects, including heart defects, thymic hypoplasia, and hypoparathyroidism. It does not typically present with dextrocardia or recurrent lung infections as a primary feature.

Option D - Down syndrome: Down syndrome is associated with a variety of congenital heart defects and may include respiratory issues. However, it is not specifically associated with dextrocardia or a particular pattern of recurrent lung infections that would align with Kartagener syndrome.

questions.text: A mother brings her daughter to the emergency room, reporting that she ingested an unknown substance. She presents with hypertension, tachycardia, hyperthermia, and mydriasis. Which of the following substances is most likely responsible for these symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C – Cocaine:

  • Cocaine acts by increasing levels of dopamine, norepinephrine, and serotonin. The symptoms described are all classic signs of cocaine intoxication.

Incorrect Options:

Options A and B – Heroin and morphine:

  • It leads to respiratory depression, hypotension, bradycardia, and pinpoint pupils (miosis).

Option D - Chlorpheniramine: It is an antihistamine and is not associated with the given symptoms.

questions.text: What is Celiac Sprue in a child?

choices.text: Anti-tissue transglutaminase (tTG) antibodies are positive and used as a screening test
A type of food allergy causing skin rashes
A genetic disorder leading to lactose intolerance
An infection in the gastrointestinal tract caused by bacteria

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Anti-tissue transglutaminase (tTG) antibodies are positive and used as a screening test:

  • Celiac sprue, also known as celiac disease, is an autoimmune disorder where the ingestion of gluten (a protein found in wheat, barley, and rye) leads to damage in the small intestine.
  • The presence of anti-tissue transglutaminase (tTG) antibodies in the blood is used as a screening test for celiac disease. This is the correct answer.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - A type of food allergy causing skin rashes:

  • Celiac disease is not a food allergy but an autoimmune disorder. While it may cause skin rashes, such as dermatitis herpetiformis, it primarily affects the small intestine and is not classified as a food allergy.

Option C - A genetic disorder leading to lactose intolerance:

  • Celiac disease is a genetic disorder but does not cause lactose intolerance directly. It is characterized by an immune reaction to gluten. However, some individuals with celiac disease may experience lactose intolerance due to damage to the intestinal lining affecting lactase production.

Option D - An infection in the gastrointestinal tract caused by bacteria:

  • Celiac disease is not an infection but an autoimmune condition. It is caused by an immune response to gluten, not by bacterial infection.

questions.text: A 65-year-old chronic alcoholic who began binge drinking ten days ago is brought to the emergency department in an unconscious state. A CT scan of his brain is normal, but his blood glucose level is 45 mg/dL. What is the most appropriate initial management?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - IM Thiamine followed by dextrose:

  • Chronic alcoholics are often thiamine-deficient. Administering glucose before thiamine can precipitate Wernicke's encephalopathy, a serious neurological disorder because glucose metabolism increases the demand for thiamine. This can lead to acute thiamine deficiency in the brain, exacerbating the condition. Therefore, giving thiamine first helps prevent this complication.

Incorrect Options:

Option A – Normal saline hydration:

  • Normal saline alone does not correct hypoglycemia.

Options C and D are incorrect, as prior thiamine supplementation is necessary before glucose administration.

questions.text: At what age is surgery typically performed for cleft lip?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 3 months

 

Explanation:

 

Surgery for cleft lip is typically performed at around 3 months of age following the "Rule of 10s", which provides safe criteria for timing of the operation:

  • 10 weeks of age

  • 10 pounds (approx. 4.5 kg) body weight

  • 10 g/dL haemoglobin

This early repair helps with feeding, speech development, and aesthetic outcomes.

 

6 months (Option B): Is later than the usual timing for cleft lip repair. By this time, cleft palate repair may be planned.

1 year (Option C): Typical age for cleft palate surgery, not lip.

18 months (Option D): Too late for primary cleft lip repair; may be considered for revision surgeries or speech surgeries if required.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding the condition shown in the image?

choices.text: Management corresponds to an improvement in the thyrotoxic state
It is not seen in 10% of patients with hyperthyroidism

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Management corresponds to an improvement in the thyrotoxic state:

  • The given image shows Kocher’s sign, which is seen in thyroid eye disease. The resection of overacting muscle LPS and resecting of underacting muscle will help to resolve the patient’s symptoms, not just the management of the thyrotoxic state.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, C, and D are true about thyroid eye diseases.

questions.text: Which drug acts on the rounded up enzyme?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Aminocaproic Acid

Explanation:

  • Aminocaproic acid is an antifibrinolytic agent that competitively inhibits plasminogen activators and, to a lesser extent, binds to plasminogen, preventing its conversion to plasmin.

  • This stabilizes fibrin clots by reducing fibrinolysis, similar to PAI-1’s effect of inhibiting tPA/uPA to limit plasmin formation.

  • By blocking fibrinolysis at the plasminogen activation step, aminocaproic acid complements PAI-1’s role in maintaining clot integrity, making it the drug of choice in conditions of excessive fibrinolysis (e.g., bleeding disorders like hemophilia or post-surgical bleeding).

 

Tenecteplase (Option B) is a fibrinolytic (thrombolytic) agent that works by directly activating plasminogen to plasmin, which breaks down fibrin clots. Tenecteplase does not act on PAI-1; instead, its action would be opposed by PAI-1 because PAI-1 inhibits tissue plasminogen activator (tPA), reducing the activation of plasminogen.

Streptokinase (Option C) is another fibrinolytic agent that works by forming a complex with plasminogen, leading to the formation of plasmin and subsequent breakdown of clots. Like tenecteplase, streptokinase's action is not directly on PAI-1, but rather on plasminogen, and its activity can be inhibited by PAI-1.

Apixaban (Option D) is an anticoagulant that works by directly inhibiting Factor Xa, an essential enzyme in the coagulation cascade. Apixaban does not interact with the fibrinolytic system or PAI-1, and its mechanism of action is unrelated to PAI-1 or plasminogen activation.

questions.text: A young woman presents with weight loss, tachycardia, heat intolerance, and tremors. On examination, she has exophthalmos. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Graves' disease:

  • Graves' disease is an autoimmune disorder that leads to hyperthyroidism. Symptoms such as weight loss, tachycardia, heat intolerance, and tremors are all characteristic of an overactive thyroid. Exophthalmos (protrusion of the eyes) is a hallmark feature of Graves' disease, distinguishing it from other thyroid conditions. This makes Graves' disease the most likely diagnosis given the patient's symptoms and findings.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Parkinson's disease: Parkinson's disease is a neurodegenerative disorder characterized by tremors, bradykinesia (slowness of movement), rigidity, and postural instability. It does not typically present with weight loss, heat intolerance, or exophthalmos, which are more suggestive of a hyperthyroid state.

Option C - Addison's disease: Addison's disease is a disorder of adrenal insufficiency characterized by symptoms such as fatigue, weight loss, hyperpigmentation, hypotension, and salt cravings. It does not typically present with tachycardia, heat intolerance, tremors, or exophthalmos, which are indicative of hyperthyroidism rather than adrenal insufficiency.

Option D - Alzheimer's disease: Alzheimer's disease is a neurodegenerative condition that primarily affects memory and cognitive function. It does not cause weight loss, tachycardia, heat intolerance, tremors, or exophthalmos, which are not associated with its clinical presentation.

questions.text: Tubectomy is typically performed at which part of the fallopian tube, and why?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Isthmus - Narrowest part :

  • The isthmus is the narrowest section of the fallopian tube, which makes it the ideal location for tubectomy.
  • This narrow part ensures that when the tube is cut or blocked, the likelihood of the eggs passing through or reconnections forming is minimal, thus providing effective sterilization.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Ampulla - Uniform thickness of muscle:

  • The ampulla is indeed a part of the fallopian tube, and while it has a relatively uniform thickness of muscle, this is not the primary reason for choosing this site for tubectomy.

Option B - Ampulla - Widest part:

  • The ampulla is the widest portion of the fallopian tube, which facilitates the passage of the ovum. However, this wide lumen is not a typical location for tubectomy as it may not provide optimal control for preventing fertilization.

Option C - Ampulla-Isthmus Junction - Site of fertilization:

  • This is the region where fertilization most commonly occurs, but performing a tubectomy here could risk the chance of incomplete sterilization.

questions.text: A patient is experiencing phantom limb pain after amputation of right limb .What is observed on a PET scan in a patient with phantom limb pain?

choices.text: Expansion of right somatosensory fibers for the hand into neighboring areas
Neighboring fibers of the right somatosensory area extending into the right-hand area

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Neighboring fibers of the right somatosensory area extending into the right-hand area:

  • After amputation, the brain undergoes cortical reorganization. In this case, the neighboring somatosensory fibers that previously represented adjacent body parts extend into the region that formerly represented the right hand. This reorganization is associated with the perception of phantom limb pain.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Expansion of right somatosensory fibers for the hand into neighboring areas:

  • This option suggests that the somatosensory fibers specifically responsible for the right hand expand into neighboring regions. However, it is not the fibers themselves that expand; rather, it is the cortical representation that changes.

Option C - Expansion of right sensory cortex:

  • This option implies a general enlargement of the right sensory cortex. However, the expansion is not global; rather, it involves the neighboring cortical areas invading the region corresponding to the amputated limb.

Option D - Expansion of left sensory cortex:

  • The left sensory cortex is responsible for processing sensory input from the right side of the body, but this option inaccurately describes the phenomenon. The reorganization occurs in the sensory cortex corresponding to the amputated limb (in this case, the right cortex, which processes left-sided sensations).

questions.text:
Match the following:


	
		
			
			 
			
			
			1
			
			
			Greater auricular nerve
			
		
		
			
			2
			
			
			Auriculotemporal nerve
			
		
		
			
			3
			
			
			Auricular branch of the vagus nerve
			
		
		
			
			4
			
			
			Lesser occipital nerve
questions.solution:
Correct Option: B) 1-C, 2-A, 3-B, 4-D

Explanation:

  • The area marked as A is supplied by the auriculotemporal nerve.
  • The area marked as B is supplied by the auricular branch of the vagus nerve.
  • The area marked as C is supplied by the greater auricular nerve.
  • The area marked as D is supplied by the lesser occipital nerve.

questions.text: A patient presents with a cerebellar mass and a renal tumor, along with a similar family history. Which of the following is responsible for his findings?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A – VHL:

  • VHL is associated with both clear cell RCC and cerebellar hemangioblastoma.

 

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C, and D are not characterized by the presence of both renal tumor and cerebellar mass.

questions.text: A man wears a female dress and high heels and gets pleasure by doing so. He was not attracted to the same gender. This condition is?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Transvestic fetishism:

Transvestic fetishism involves wearing clothing traditionally associated with the opposite sex for sexual arousal. It is characterized by deriving sexual pleasure from cross-dressing, without necessarily having an attraction to the same gender. The person in this scenario finds pleasure in wearing female clothing and high heels but is not attracted to the same sex.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Voyeurism:
Voyeurism involves gaining sexual pleasure from watching others who are unaware that they are being watched, particularly in intimate or private situations. It is not related to cross-dressing or deriving pleasure from wearing the clothing of the opposite sex.

Option C - Sexual dysphoria:
Sexual dysphoria (more commonly referred to as gender dysphoria) is the distress or discomfort that may occur when an individual's gender identity does not align with their assigned sex at birth. This condition involves a disconnect between one’s experienced gender and the gender assigned at birth, not the act of cross-dressing for pleasure.

Option D - Gay orientation:
Gay orientation refers to an attraction to individuals of the same gender. The scenario described does not involve sexual attraction to the same sex but rather involves deriving pleasure from wearing clothing typically associated with the opposite sex.
